Etta James summed up my love affair with brunch when she serenaded the words, "Sunday Kind of Love."

A late morning, freshly squeezed orange juice, a chalk board of egg delights, and a railway of bacon makes it difficult to not drown in the ambiance of Sunday.

Squat & Gobble is a home to families, dogs, and the true '2nd' date of the weekend. A place where sweats are acceptable, lounging, and reminiscing of the shenanigans of the night before are custom.

Blueberry pancakes top the list as a favorite here, and their omelets have never failed.   

They have a wonderful hidden back patio, that streams in light like a blockbuster.

2011 resolution. More brunch. More Sunday, Kind of Love.

Here's to another great year Yelpers, lets eat 'till we drop. :)
author: Mike K.

description:
Service was really quick.  Great food.  Angus cheesesteak was juicy, very flavorful French onion soup, veggie burger was homemade and delicious.  

Dessert crepes are excellent, even to go.  Definitely want to come try more menu options.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
When I walked into Squat & Gobble with an empty stomach, I marveled at the very varied menu. After ordering the eggs florentine, I wasn't sure if I made the right choice. Eggs florentine is a hard dish to perfect, and I was very much craving a rich and delicious hollandaise sauce. After the rough morning I'd had, I was going to be very sad if it didn't turn how I'd hoped. 

The food arrived within 15 minutes, which was perfect because my hunger was only increasing. As I took my first bite, I was so happy that I ordered this dish instead of something else. The eggs were cooked just the way I like them, the English muffin was soggy-to-perfection, the hollandaise was creamy and smooth, and the Rosemary potatoes had so much flavor. I ate every last bite. I will definitely be back!
author: Sofia F.

description:
Stopped in there yesterday for a late-afternoon small meal and ordered the chicken ceasar salad to go. 

Good sized portion. Cooked to order fresh chicken breast on top of salad. Friendly employees. Little on the expensive side. 

Won't be running back for the salad but if I happen to be around there, wouldn't mind stopping in to check out some more of their menu!
author: Lauren S.

description: Good inexpensive food with all varieties from Chinese to burgers. Good for families who want different things. Service was fast
author: Sun B.

description: The wifes Crepe was delicious. I had the Burbon street omlette. Was supposed to have homemade spicey sausage but resembled more of chili without bean... not what one would be expecting. Decore was old fashion but inviting and service was nice. Could have recieved higher score but the omlette just did not deliver for me
author: Eugene B.

description:
Gotta love brunch!  I felt like this place was more like a 3.5, because it didn't have me going mm-mm-good, but since everything seemed to work out without any setbacks, I bumped it up to a 4!

I had the grilled salmon sandwich, served on focaccia bread with a side of salad.  The salad was nice, but the potatoes here are pretty tasty.  Next time I'm getting the potatoes or fruit as a side.  Anyway, everything is standard-good.  I found myself reaching over to everyone else's plate and taking a bite or two.  Everyone seemed to like their savory crepes, and the yogurt parfait was tasty.  This is definitely a dependable eatery!
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
Great place with incredibly underrated food! The crab melt is a must and the best kept secret us a small patio in the alley beside the restaurant...I just stumbled
Across it!
author: Greg H.

description:
One of the best meals I have had while visiting San Francisco.  Had the portabello  sandwich with side salad.  All the veggies on the sandwich were perfectly roasted, and the salad was also really good, the dressing tasted like it had a bit of hot sauce mixed in with it, which was good if you like hot stuff.

I would absolutely eat here again.
author: Laura O.

description: The Squat & Gobble restaurants are fun, tasty, and fulfilling options- in my opinion best for weekend brunches.  There are a wide variety of options to fulfill anyones preferences- most notable are the wide variety of both savory and sweet crepes.  Additionally, there are a number of cost-effective options on the children's menu.  Nothing I have had or shared has stricken me as an 'all-star' plate, but everything is 'good or better', and the pickiest of eaters will be able to find something to enjoy- omelets, waffles, bagels, pancakes, fruit dishes, or others...Go with tempered expectations and you will leave with a smile at a reasonable price.
author: Andy S.

description:
This place is all around awesome.

Whether you're in the mood for breakfast, salads, sandwiches or even something from the Wok, they've got it all and they are equally tasty. Order in line then take your number and they deliver the food to your table. 

You have the option of indoor seating (but with large windows that open to the sidewalk) or outdoor seating either in the front on the sidewalk or in the spacious and heated back patio. I've sat both places and the noise level and ambiance are consistently mellow. 

We went during very busy weekends when all the bars and restaurants in the area were packed. While this place was crowded, it offered a nice refuge from the bustle outside. Awesome casual dining experience with great food to boot - definitely stop in!
author: Mallory P.

description: I live in the neighborhood and have tried a lot of things on the menu. Pretty much everything is great. Staff is friendly and helpful. Service is normally incredibly fast. Two thumbs up!
author: David B.

description:
Okay, so not sure if this was an OFF day but my friends and I had the worst experience here. 2/5 of our meals had hairs in them. Our food took 30 minutes to come out and the waiter had not mentioned anything or apologized that the food was taking so long. Our food came out cold and it was horrible. We all tried different things and the only eatable dish was the eggs benedict. 

Why would anyone go here when the Grove is across the street?
author: Jenna Q.

description:
Matt was here yesterday prior to this review for a quick lunch. The place wasn't really too crowded at the exact time of the midday, but parking in the Marina was a nightmare, even with his work car. He had a large bowl of the Vegetarian Black Bean Chili. The $4.75 large bowl of spicy Chili was very tasty and filling. 

Matt enjoyed the restaurant so much, he took the rest of the Fantastic-4 members for breakfast the next day, before Matt goes off work. (Yes, Matt actually works on Saturdays) A very surprising scene for a Saturday morning in the Marina; the restaurant was also not too crowded either and we were seated immediately. Matt ordered the Fillmore Omelette. The specialized Omelette, which contained shredded cheddar cheese, sliced ham, mushrooms, & bell-peppers, is very similar to a Denver Omelette you get at any breakfast joint. Matt's meal, which costs $8.95, also had a Rosemary-Garlic Potatoes and a toasted plain Bagel. There are 5 specialized omelettes at this place, and each of them have locations of each Squats and Gobbles named after their omelettes. Matt and wife also ordered a endless cup of needed coffee. 

Wife, who was hungry, ordered the Crab-Cake Florentine. The $9.25 meal had 2 crab cakes, 2 poached eggs on a English-Muffin smothered with a creamy, but salty Hollandaise Sauce on top and the same roasted spuds on the side. Her meal was very tasty, but needed to drink a lot of water after the sauce. The kids order OJ ($2.50),split a bowl of Granola w/yogurt and a Bagel and Cream Cheese. The $5.00 granola was very fresh and crunchy, and complimented well with the yogurt. It was so crunchy that most of the patrons can hear them crunch loudly from their mouths. The $2.00 Bagel w/ Cream Cheese was nothing too special, but just a plain toasted bagel with cream cheese. 

Our meal was good. In the future, we would like to check out other items .i.e. specialized crepes at this restaurants and visit the other locations. Sadly, Matt's time with family was brief, because he has to go to work.
author: Matt G.

description:
THIS PLACE IS GROSS!  We've been eating out a lot lately due to a strained thumb and wrist, so I can't cook.  My blood sugar was low and it was time for my snack; I practically staggered over to this place after the OJ I drank at The Grove wasn't enough for my blood sugar.  

To be healthy, we both ordered salads with dressing on the side.  I got the greek, my hubby got the crab salad (I don't know why he would get seafood at this place, but didn't say a word).  They came and it was a huge unappealing mess of brown tinged greens, messily put together; it wasn't very fresh and the crab, it was a light brownish red colour (not fresh looking nor fresh smelling), but we ate them, b/c we paid $25 and we needed sustenance.  I regretted my decision and stumbled out feeling disgusting like I ate rotting food, which I did.  Squat and Gobble, I don't like you!
author: Miss H.

description:
A friend of mine was recommended to try Squat & Gobble while we were on a weekend trip to San Francisco. We were glad for the recommendation! 
The staff was very friendly for our Saturday lunch visit. A good choice for a fast casual experience. The food was delicious but nothing that absolutely blew my mind. A great location and enjoyable experience. I would definitely return if in the area. I loved the various mimosas!
author: sara m.

description: Great food, friendly service, moderate prices for chestnut st. Highly recommend the crepes, but all the food is tasty. Great variety ranging from pancakes to pan-asian.
author: D B.

description: Think you can't have a savory crepe... Think again. Vegetable crepe with veggie chili was amazing- especially when topped with crispy tortilla thins!  Sweet, salty, spicy...in one bite!
author: Madison B.

description: Cutest place ever!! Food is great and back patio garden is amazing do pretty and cozy!!! Makes it very enjoyable to eat out there!!!!
author: Anosha A.

description:
One of the friendlier cashier/busboy run establishments in the area. They work super hard and do a great job. I like that you can eat sinfully or healthy here and I also like that you can substitute all you want without getting the eye-roll. The somewhat-hidden back patio is key on sunny days.

Overall, this place is just solid.
author: Meredith R.

description: Had a great experience for brunch. they have a cute patio in the back which was beautiful on a sunny day. the coffee was great, the omelette was great and they were very helpful with the substitution,  the service was perfect as well. I would love to come back.
author: A S.

description:
This is really at 2.5 star review.

Came in for brunch over the weekend and our group of 5 had 4 separate orders.  The last person who ordered got his food first...waited another 5 minutes and our friend who showed up 10 minute late got his order next and then finally about 15 minutes after the first plate showed up to the table the rest of the table got their food.  Service was very slow and inconsistent.  We had 3 or 4 different waiters waiting on us and had to ask for napkins, utensils for them to refill out drinks multiple times after the food came out. 

The food it self was ok.  I had the french toast and my wife had the eggs Benedict.  The french toast was not "eggy" enough.  You can tell it was quickly dipped in the egg wash and it didn't really soak trough.  My wife's dish was pretty good though.  We also ended our brunch with a strawberry crepe.  It was good however the over dusted our crepe with too much cinnamon.

This place would get a higher start rating if they could just work out the service kinks.
author: Henry S.

description: The food was good - I got the smoked salmon scramble with potatoes for brunch but don't expect them to come by and refill waters or coffee! The service is slow but I guess they are usually pretty busy and just hustling to get the food out to customers.
author: Jing L.

description:
This place is strange. Or maybe not. Maybe I am just used to brunch places in Sacramento that allow you to have a glass of water while you wait for your table. I went to the Squat & Gobble after the Men's Health Urbanathlon. My party went up to the counter, placed our order, and went to the patio entrance, where we were told that we would have to wait for a table. Next to the patio entrance, we noticed that there was a huge water station with dozens of glasses of ice water. We also saw that a couple people who were also waiting to be seated had glasses of water. So we assumed that it would be no problem grabbing a glass of water to drink while we waited to be seated. We were wrong. Well, two members of our party of five had good timing and grabbed a glass of water without being detected. But when I went up to the water station and grabbed a glass of water, a busboy grabbed my arm and removed the glass from my hand. I said that we were waiting for a table on the patio and wanted a glass of water while we waited. The busboy said no. Water would be brought to us after we were seated. Undeterred, I removed my arm from his grasp and picked up another glass of water. He grabbed my arm again. I said: "Really? We can't have a glass of water while we wait to be seated?" And as I was starting to explain that running 10 miles with obstacles makes a person thirsty and irritable, I found myself surrounded by two busboys and someone who appeared to be the manager, all of whom were telling me to "put the water down" like it was a weapon. I believe I said something like: "All I want is some f*#@ing water while we wait for our table." I had other things to say, but the manager-looking man kept interrupting me with: "Sir, please. Sir. Sir. Sir, please. Sir. Sir. Let go of the water. Sir. Please, sir. Sir, please. Sir. Put the water down. Sir. Thank you. Sir. Sir. Put the water down." Meanwhile, the busboy was still holding my arm. At this point, the incident had become so funny that I started laughing, put the water down, and returned to the patio entrance to wait for the table. As promised, water was brought to our table when we sat down. But why not let us have a drink of water during our 20-minute wait? The whole thing seemed ridiculous. 

Aside from the water incident, the food was good, not extraordinary, but good. My coffee was great, but it took way too long to get a refill. We were seated next to a service station with a coffee pot. I considered refilling my cup on my own, but after what happened with the water, I decided against it.
author: Nicholas M.

description:
A Sunday morning, I stopped by for a brunch. BUT, everything goes wrong. You have to be patient to dine here on weekend I guess! 
We had wait for 15 mins to receive glasses of water. For our dishes, a portobello sandwich and special salsa crepe, took our more then 30mins to wait! How's that possible!? Half room of people were waiting, waiting, and waiting... 

Finally, we complained to the manager and told him we want the food Togo instead! Unbelievable...

Manager tried to fix our complaint by rushing the kitchen and offering complimentary drinks. However, we just don't have the mood to dine in anymore.
 
The portobello sandwich is pretty good! Any my friend's crepe isn't bad either! the quality of food is good but not the service!

Wanna dine here for a nice brunch? You'd better be really patient and not in a rush!!!!!
author: JustinE Y.

description:
I totally dig a clean bathroom in a restaurant and the one in the patio area was outstanding, made my while in there worth staying, plus the music plays pretty loud so enjoyed my tinkle with a little toe tapping rhythm, TMI?  Discovered this place on a day that I played hooky from work to enjoy the rare nice weather...LOVED the back patio area.  Enjoyed listening to the music and just took in the atmosphere.

My ruben sandwich was thinner than I expected, but it was good.  The sliced prime rib sandwich was also good, but on the skimpy side too.  From the looks of the salads we saw passing us by it seems that salads were the big deal here (they looked huge), not the crepes.  Worth the ambience in the patio area on a nice sunny day, and go on a weekday.
author: Emy B.

description: it is just fantastic !!! very cool place with great food. ( for crab cake lovers)- amazing crab cake florentine. Great for brunch!!!
author: Ilya K.

description:
What a horrible dining experience. My husband and I came here for Sunday brunch on our anniversary weekend, as I recognized the name from having been here with a friend in the past. 

When we walked in, we were greeted by a wall of noise and a line to order that was almost to the door. The line was moving fast though, so we assumed that the food would be too. Boy, were we wrong. It took fifteen minutes for me to get my iced tea, and then only after asking for it twice. Our food took another 40 minutes to arrive, and then only after asking about that, too. 

When it did arrive, my salmon salad was dry and lukewarm, while my husband's omelet was warm and fresh. Very clearly they'd forgotten our order until the waitress asked about it, then quickly made the omelet and sent both out. No apologies were made for the tardiness of the food, and when we ordered a mimosa to calm my very hungry and annoyed nerves, they didn't offer to comp it. 

All of this would have been fine except we were sitting in a room so noisy and crowded we couldn't hear each other talking. I can handle loud and crazy restaurants if they're quick, OR slow service if the ambiance is good. Not both. I get that it was a busy Sunday and they were swamped, but that is no excuse. 

Guaranteed we will not be eating here again, nor recommending it to friends.
author: Zoe E.

description:
We were heading to Judy's, but, when we realized that they don't take credit cards, we ran across the street to the S&Q Cafe.

The place is clean and set up really well. The staff was very friendly and helpful! 

It lost a star on me. The wife loved her South of the Border omelette and she loved it...5 star for her! I had the Triple gobble. It was ok-good, but nothing WOW. I'd get an omelette on the next trip to the city!
author: Bob P.

description: A great breakfast place! The food was fresh, I loved my Crab Cake Florentine dish. It had me full all the way until dinner time. :) Price is not overkill either.
author: Jennifer D.

description: i got my food for take out..i was impressed with the service i got and italian crepe melted in my mouth the only thing i was unhappy with was the take out box and the rosemary potatos wasn't all that....it was to greasy..my poor crepe looked like it needed some breathing room in the box they put it in..but other then that i like
author: Mike S.

description:
Sure, it's a chain... but a local one and they sure know breakfast. S&G is my second favorite breakfast joint in the Marina, right underneath Rose's down the street. Don't expect anything innovative on the culinary scale, just a solid done-right breakfast with fresh ingredients.

This is definitely the spot for typical heart-warming breakfast comfort food, prepared relatively quickly and within typical Bay Area price ranges.

The only con is how awkward the name sounds when recommending "Squat and Gobble"
author: Blake B.

description:
I was drawn here by their $20 dinner for 1.  App, entree and glass of wine?  Can't beat that.  Should have realized why...

Apps:  Curried mussels...  Overcooked mussel jerky!!!  So overcooked the shells shattered like wafers.  You might think, why didn't you return it?  Well for $20 bucks, I guess I should have known the quality of food they were going to be serving so I almost blame myself instead of them lol... Curry sauce was okay though...   

Entree:  Poached salmon...  o.m.g.  EW EW EW EW EW.  The salmon itself was poached fine, not over cooked or anything, but omg.  NO flavor. The goop that was the vegetable melange?  NO flavor.  (Plus it was covered in some thick flavorless sauce so I couldn't tell what vegetables there were).  I kept on throwing salt on it and it wasn't fixing it.  Oh and the weirdest part?  They served it with a side of tzatziki?!?!  What?!  Why?!  I tried it because I thought it would make it better but no.  No it didn't.  

I left SO sad and disappointed.  I didn't even finish my wine.  :-/  I was that turned off. 

They got 2 stars instead of 1 because the server was very attentive and they kept my water glass full.  Will not return :(
author: Jammir G.

description:
I had a florentine crepe here and it was really good and filling. I added chicken which was unnecessary, but my eyes are usually bigger than my tummy anyway. I wanted to love this place, but it took forever to get our order- so much so that I had to ask for it to go so it was kind of soggy by the time I got to eat it.

I'll try this place again, maybe get a mimosa with fresh oj and hopefully I'll update to more stars.
author: JoAnn P.

description:
We'd noticed the sign the last time we visited SF and decided to stop in for a bite while exploring the neighborhood. Must say, I love a place that serves breakfast all the time.

We ordered at the counter so there isn't much opportunity to rate the service, other than the guy at checkout was friendly and patient, and at the table our glasses were consistently filled, and plates cleared in a timely manner despite being taken care of by 4 different servers/bussers. 

Food was pretty good. I had the Crab Cake Florentine, and really how can you go wrong with poached eggs, spinach and an english muffin? That said the crab cake was so-so. I would have expected better in SF, but I did pay like 12 bucks so what can I expect. My side was the black bean vegetarian chili and as someone who has tried to find a good recipe at home I can confirm this was a great one!
He ordered the Upper Haight Omelette and it was a wonderful and interesting combination of flavors. The side of rosemary potatoes were excellent! 

Highlights: the fresh-squeezed orange juice, a very well--flavored, though light, Chai latte, and the fact that we paid $30 for an obscene amount of food. The pricing is pretty awesome, so if you are pretty hungry and relatively broke, I recommend it!
author: Bridgette M.

description:
This place is close to home and has some great food for brunch and lunchtime treats! 

Met some gals here in Sunday for brunch and of coarse a few mimosas! They were packed, but did a good job with servicing everyone and getting the food out as quick as possible. 

The omelets are great and the crepes are fantastic! 

I love their mimosas made with fresh squeezed orange juice! 

Great spot to catch up with friends and enjoy a tasty meal!
author: Kelly B.

description:
I love their hollandaise sauce (among the best I've had). But the eggs on the benedict & florentine barely qualify as poached! So runny, it floods the rest of the plate at first cut.  And every time I ask for "medium" poached, the eggs are almost hard boiled.

Crepes are good, omelettes are a bit greasy but good.  

Probably next best place in Marina for working while having options for various hot food, since the Grove closed. :(
author: CuNyc S.

description: If you are walking around Chestnut St and you see 100's of restaurants, GO to Squat and Gobble.  Food is delicious; fun atmosphere; fair prices. Back patio is quite and nice.  I had pasta, and it was really good.
author: Susan M.

description:
I recommend the Crab Cake Benedict. 

They serve sizeable portions, and the environment is very pleasant--especially the back patio.
author: K L.

description: Went there for breakfast. Neat little place, but the service was not good. They were understaffed, which is a bit ridiculous when you consider you order at a counter. Waited a good while for our food & when we got it, it was clear why... all plates of food were cold.
author: Patrick D.

description: 10% yelp discount- nice. Chose this place because we could walk to the Palace of Fine Arts afterward, which was lovely. Tasty eggs benedict.
author: Meghan B.

description: I fell in love with their French toast! By far the best French toast I've ever tasted!  would definitely recommend this!
author: Meg C.

description:
Great brunch spot!  4 gals and a baby ordered 5 dishes, 2 alcoholic drinks and 2 regular drinks for $67...no problem here - especially when the food was good!

I love the menus, so easy to read and makes me want to order everything! I had the spaghettini w/ chicken, so simple yet so tasty! The breakfast potatoes were crunchy just the way I like them and the pancakes topped off the meal. I wanted to order the crepes but  decided not to since we had pancakes. 

This restaurant is in a great spot, the Marina has so much to do after your done with Squat and Gobble!
author: Yvonne N.

description: The Squat and Gobble is a great brunch/ breakfast place! They've got a large menu with everything from sweet and savory crepes to pasta and a wok kitchen. Their fresh orange juice is very delicious and the croissant sandwich is good as well. The service is great and it's a great place for kids.
author: Chloe K.

description:
Breakfast is delicious, filling, and fairly reasonably priced. 
Now I'm craving some benedict...
author: Makena S.

description:
Terrific brunch place: really nice folks, good typical brunch fare, fast service, and with plenty of seating including 2 outdoor areas: sidewalk tables in front and a patio in the rear.

I've never had an issue here even last weekend as part of a group of 8 people.  Highly recommend you squat here for a while and gobble some of their good grub.
author: David A.

description: Not bad. Many other joints were so crowded around here. This place is pretty big and serves up decent coffee, grub, and beer. Add a few TVs showing baseball and you have a nice cross between a cafe and a bar. All at a reasonable price.
author: James S.

description:
Although I live down the street from Squat and Gobble, I didn't hear the best things from other fellow Marina diners, and the name is just a unique one... reminds me of Thanksgiving! Anyways, it's got a decent ambiance, casual setting, and is quick. As it's strengths are dessert crepes and purportedly, breakfast (omelettes and crepes), my friend and I came in for a Sunday brunch to recover from the weekend. It's one of those joints where you order at the counter and then self-seat, and they bring your food to you. The service was really okay, and no one really checks on you, but delivers your food. They are nice, just not overtly service-friendly. 

First of all, portion size is HUGE! I had enough left over from breakfast fro at least two more subsequent days. My friend had the Marina crepe (Cheddar, onions, pesto, eggplant, Feta, olives, red peppers, artichokes and tomatoes) which was okay,  but nothing to write home about. I had the South of the Border omelette (Jack cheese, black bean chili and avocado topped with salsa and sour cream) which had WAY too much egg. My mistake was to not order egg whites, because there was so much egg, I was full within the first 4 bites. I was saving my stomach for the strawberry nutella dessert crepe, anyways! 

Point of clarification - there is a regular "nutella chocolate" crepe, a "strawberry nutella" crepe and a "fresh strawberry" crepe. If you are desiring of a nutella crepe with fresh strawberries, which would you order?? If you said "strawberry nutella" you are correct. It comes with smatterings of nutella (yum!) and fresh strawberries baked within. I'm sure we thoroughly confused the girl at the counter... and the freshly squeezed OJ??? Is it just me, or are oranges not in season?? They have a juicer which is viewable at the counter, but the oranges were so bitter...  Although the food was fine,  and the prices were fair, this is probably not a place I would take any guests who are diehard foodies.
author: Tammy H.

description: Pretty solid spot for brunch on a Sunday.  The eggs benedict was good, not great, but the back patio is one of the nicer ones I've seen in the area - I had no idea it was there.  Based on the photos I now see on their Yelp page, I am looking forward to trying a crepe next time.
author: Tony B.

description: Another nice brunch place in the Castro! We arrived around 1:30pm and the line wasn't bad. We were worried about seating since it was pretty crowded but luckily the line moved quickly and the staff finds a table for you. We chose to sit outside to enjoy the sunshine & the view. We had the Belgian waffle, crab cake benedict and eggs benedict. The benedicts were very rich and the home potatoes quite tasty! The waffle was a little on the dry side. My only gripe is the food took a while to come out ~30 min or so... Total for 2 people including drinks ~ $32.
author: Cheryl P.

description: On a trip to SF with my boyfriend, we found ourselves wandering by the Marina looking for a place to get breakfast on our way to the Golden Gate bridge.  We found out this place was near-by and decided to give it a try based on the name alone!  I couldn't be happier!  I ordered a cappichino and the banana-chocolate-walnut crepe and my BF got the rueben with roasted potatoes and a caffe mocha.  We decided to sit in the back patio since it was so nice out.  The patio area is gorgeous and I highly recommend sitting out there if it is remotely a nice day.  My crepe was fan-tas-tic.  It was cooked to perfection with some extra crispy sugary pieces.  I got it with vanilla bean ice cream and it came with a huge dollap of real whipped cream and the combination of it all was too good for words.  Only one thing I had topped my crepe and that was the potatoes.  Oh. my. lord.  Those potatoes are some of the best things I have put in my mouth.  Rosemary, thyme and garlic and again, they were cooked to perfection having just the right amount of crispiness on the them.  I have nothing bad to say about this place.  The wait staff was nice and attentive and the prices are good for what you get.  Highly recommend!
author: Kara R.

description: A rice big stone came out from my crepe. They should ask for a refound but they offered me a dessert. I think they consider me as lucky guy. Poor management mantelity.
author: Fatih E.

description:
Wonderfully fresh ingredients!

Came here with my family and ordered a grilled salmon sandwich, asian chicken salad, house salad, and grilled chicken sandwich.

Everything tasted really fresh and flavorful! And the salads were quite filling! Definitely recommend for a nice lunch or brunch - there's tons of options on the menu!
author: Connie Y.

description: Today was my boyfriends birthday. Perfect weather. Patio seating. Great ambiance and amazing crepes! I got the marina crepe with salmon capers olives mozzarella and sundries tomatoes. So good. The service was awesome too. We had a great conversation with a 97 year old guy next to us who apparently was a regular. Loved it.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
Brunch is by far my favorite meal.  There is something special about coming together with a group of friends on a sunny morning and indulging in some hearty breakfast food.  

This place is known for its crepes and they deliver that very well.  The other items on the menu were good but not phenomenal.  From an ambiance perspective, it felt a little commercial (think...chain hotel brunch).  That said, service was decent and I came away feeling that the establishment was at the least dependable and good.

I'd return, but I rarely venture to this part of the city.
author: Aasim K.

description:
I came here with a couple of friends for breakfast but have never heard of it before.  It was a great find and reasonably priced.

I am not big on eating eggs but have started to eat them recently again.  My friend and I split the eggs Benedict and the strawberry blintz crepe.  I realize now I cannot eat runny eggs but once I got passed that everything was excellent (even the water tasted good).  The service was great also.
author: Beth T.

description: The place is cute.  The menu is a wide variety of sugary goodness and healthy mother earth type items.  The coffee drinks were huge but not piping hot.  I got waffles with nutella, bananas, brown sugar and nuts.  It was a little stingy on the nutella, but overall delicious.  My buddy got the mediterranean crepe that was chocked full of feta, cheddar, peppers, eggs, artichokes and tomatoes.  It was YUMMY!  This place gets packed so go early or go with patience.
author: Mimi D.

description: Went to this place for dinner a few nights ago.  My friend had one of the dessert crepes and absolutely loved it. I got the grilled Reuben, and it was decent. Not the best Reuben I've ever had for sure, but it wasn't the worst.  Cute atmosphere inside, although the line could have been a bit shorter.  Lots of potential here, but I hear there is fresh squeezed orange juice mimosas, so I might have to head back for some of those!
author: Alex B.

description:
Came for lunch on a Sunday.

You order up front and are given a number to take to your table (seat yourself). Your food will come out promptly.

Not crowded. Food was ready quickly (not too quick so you feel that it wasnt personally made for you).
We sat in the back patio area. Heat lamp was on and it was a totally chill atmosphere (perfect for a Sunday afternoon).

Had the Zorba the Greek Crepe with the side of potatoes (what can I say, I'm a sucker for spinach). Definitely recommended, though everything our group looked great.

Our friend arrived late and ordered the blueberry pancakes. Sitting even 3 ppl down, I could smell that blueberry and pancake sweetness. 

Great menu (crepes, omelets, sandwiches, salads). Great for a delicious, laid back breakfast/lunch or light dinner.
author: Norman P.

description:
Although it's got a weird name, the Squat and Gobble on Chesnut's food is fantastic. Specializing in crepes, they are fresh, tasty and not expensive.

Try the huge dinner for two at $30 bucks. A great deal, although I managed to have dessert, too. Wups.

Big thanks to the great management.
author: Fireball Tim L.

description: This place is great because it's like an upscale ihop. You still get the large breakfast portions (+++++), but you also get mint & lemon infused water and fresh squeezed OJ! Yummm. We were there around 11 for Saturday brunch and the place fills up quickly! It took awhile to get our food. This was a little troubling because I had an internal conflict at the register and couldn't bring myself to spend $20 on breakfast so I decided to forgo coffee. (OJ and sub French Toast adds up) The whole time I was sitting there wishing that I'd ordered coffee. When we asked the server about our food status, he said the problem was that there are more servers than cooks. Ooops! Anyway, he hooked me up with some coffee as a re-fill on my friend's. Yee! They do service well!
author: Erin H.

description:
Honestly, I'd give this place 3.5 stars, but it's closer to the 4 mark than 3.

The food here is great!  I ordered the Upper Height Omelette with fruit.  What they don't tell you is that there is a surcharge for fruit rather than potatoes, but hey, eating healthy ain't cheap!  

Portion sizes are large, service was prompt, and environment was clean and very friendly.  Great place for breakfast/brunch/lunch but there will certainly be a wait on the weekends.  I'll be back next time I want a $15 breakfast.  :)
author: Yeelo N.

description: Great food and great patio! They have awesome French fries and the salmon sandwich is delicious :)
author: Heather N.

description:
There is something called comfort food and this is why I come here all the time. crepes is my thing, whenever I am down and out and need a boost.

I love salmon based dishes and their marina crepe (which has salmon) is what satisfies me.

banana, nutella and berries crepe  with vanilla icecream is the tipping point for me to give this place a 4/5 stars which has otherwise decent food.

experimented with their other dishes but no success.
author: Utsav M.

description:
Been here just once but I will definitely come back.
They had this amazing flight of local beer deal for $2.50 with the purchase of a meal. Yes. Two dollars and fifty cents for generous servings of four different beers. I was buzzing after drinking $1.25 worth.

The menu is vary diverse and not at all expected albeit a bit eclectic: burgers, crepes, salads, pasta, Asian dishes and breakfast dishes. I had the Prawns & Giant Shanghai
Noodles In Broth and it was pretty darn good! I was skeptical of Asian food in a non-Asian restaurant but it was good and I'd get it again though I might try some other dishes first!

The cashier was also really helpful and made sure we were utilizing the best deal (they have a weekday discount when you purchase 2 dishes which is better than the Yelp check-in deal), which was above and beyond.
author: K C.

description:
I have walked past for almost 2 years, never once venturing inside. 

But last weekend we were looking for somewhere to take some friends without walking too far. We can across this place, it was busy but I found a table out the back (it was a lovely day) and we all ordered. I was holding the table so didn't get the chance to see the menu. But the food was good. 

Fast forward to last night, heading to see a movie and wanted to have something to eat - fast and warm. And wandered in, it was not too full. I found something nice on the menu - the Hawaiian Crepe. I customized by removing the sausage = veggi with the included side of potatoes. It was awesome, much better than I expected, it really has become an instant go-to place. 

While the outside doesn't look amazing the inside is comfortable with a good range of food and efficient friendly service.
author: Ross s.

description:
Just finished their Mamma Mia crepes.  In a word-yum! I was inthe mood for something breakfasty but was also sort of craving Italian food, so the Mamma Mia crepes, described as "cheddar, mozzarella, cottage cheese, onions, mushrooms, spinach, eggplant, tomatoes and walnuts topped with marinara sauce and parmesan cheese" sounded good.  It also sounded like, if done wrong, it could be a disaster, but that marinara sounded so good, i had to do it.

The crepes themselves were flavourful, the fillings all done just right, not over or undercooked, very fresh tasting.  The walnuts were a lovely surprise- i didnt see at first howthey'd pair up with an italian themed entree, but they worked great and really gave the whole thing a lil something extra. The crepes were topped with just the right amount of marinara- a few tablespoons...same with the parmwesan cheese on top.

Th pota
The side dish home fries were good too, if a tiny bit tough.  Mighht want to keep an eye on them and make suenthey not too old or tough in the future.  That's a mimor quibble though.  I'm happy  i stoppd  by the Squat and Gobble this morning, and i'll definitely be back :)
author: Mer L.

description:
the atmosphere here is good.  they have a garden in the back which is great for parties, even for breakfast.  it is very big.  once you walked in, you may place your order.  i don't know to how tip because it is like a regular coffee shop which you order your food, they give you a number, then you sit down, the servers bring you the food. 

the restroom is clean.   I gave it 4 stars because of the nice atmosphere and the friendly cashiers and staff. 

the crab meat florentine benedict is only really really alright.  it  did not suprise my tastebud, the crab meat somehow taste like fish,  i have no proof that's fresh from live crabs or from can.  then the potatoes are cooked black.  they taste like they marinated with herb.  I don't know what kind of spice they use. 

French toast with strawberries on top.  the strawberries are not freshly cut a minute ago, they looked like they cut all the fruits early in the morning.  the nice thing is they serve heavy whipped cream with it. 

However, i like their lemon mint water.   they have a big selection of menu.  I haven't tried all of them so I can't give it a 3 based on the two dish i tried.
author: Kentaro K.

description:
Very cute find!  With the new baby in tow, we're always looking for "kid-friendly" places.  Right when we walked in, we saw 2 babies with strollers - nice!

I like that they have specials on boards outside and chalkboard menu on the walls inside.  There's a lot to choose from so take your time!

I ordered the rueben sandwich - YUMMO.  The salad that comes with it is a decent size.  The pickeled... stuff..... that comes with it is good too!  Hubs ordered some beefy sandwich (prime rib I think? can't remember).  His plate was licked clean.  Also ordered the apple pie crepe.  Totally tasted like apple pie!  Love that the ice cream was in a little dish so it didn't melt and swirl into everything.

Also love that the baby changing table is outside the bathroom so mom can yell for extra diapers from dad at the table :) Plus my girl hates those things when they're in the bathroom.  Something about the echo and being in a confined space freaks her out.

Anyway...where was I.....?

We will definitely be back - love the atmosphere, staff was super friendly, and food was bomb.
author: Paulette L.

description: The chicken pesto crepe is delicious! I also really enjoyed the Mexican Grilled Chicken salad. Tasty, quick, and relatively inexpensive!
author: Lydia A.

description: Haven't tried the Crêpes yet but had few other items and the food was very good and reasonably priced. They even have a back patio that is very nice and allows dogs
author: Aziz S.

description:
Came here for dinner last night, usually love this place for breakfast but was in for a rude awakening.

I started off with the sake mussels, which were pretty good. A little overcooked, but tasty and a delicious curry sauce added a nice flavor. 

The entree that followed was what warranted the 2 stars. I had the baby back ribs, which came out dry and tough. It was the exact opposite of "fall off the bone". It was accompanied by baked beans, which were decent, corn on the cob, which was undercooked and awful, and a dry piece of cornbread. Overall, I had to force down every part of the entree except the baked beans.
author: Perry C.

description: I love this place SO much! I have never been disappointed with any of my food! My favorites include the Salmon Cobb Salad, the French Onion Soup, and the Portabello Stack Sandwich!  Sit out in the back patio, sip a mimosa, and enjoy the sun!
author: Jessyca M.

description: The breakfast trifecta! Great service, great overall food, and (most importantly to me) great breakfast potatoes. We each had omelets, and they were both tasty. Highly recommend this place. I will definitely return!
author: J.D. W.

description: I've been here for breakfast and dinner and both times were such a disappointment.  The food isn't really well made and some of the seasonings used make the food taste kind of funky.  I feel badly saying that because the staff are so friendly, but I just can't stomach the food.
author: Julie P.

description: Boyfriend and I ate here after the SF Undie Run. I ordered the Chicken Pesto crepe with pesto on the side and the bf ordered some other savory crepe. Both were pretty good, the food came out at a decent time, seating wasn't hard to find. We sat outiside in the patio and they have heat lamps and a TV. Portions were a good size as in just enough, not obscene amounts or mouse food.
author: J N.

description:
Our usual breakfast spot. 
You order your food at the counter and they bring it over to your table. 
There is a very nice outdoor sitting are in the back, which is really nice for those warm summer days. 

The breakfast food is great. A wide variety of crepes, with the option of potatoes, salad or fruit. For me, the best item on the menus is the Mediterranean Crepe, which comes with feta cheese, pesto sauce, eggplant...  it's really an "explosion" of flavor. But you should add their chicken apple sausage on the side, to make THE complete breakfast. 

BUT, beware of the onion... Lots of it in the crepes, and typically not well grilled, just warm... almost raw. Remove it or ask them to grill it first (I will next time!)

Their Iced Cappuccino is not on the menu, but they do a great job. Funny how everyone on adjacent tables asks what that is when it comes out. 

It gets pretty busy on the weekends, so sometimes the wait for the food is long.  But nice place for breakfast and catch up with friends.
author: Michel A.

description: Great food. Fresh and flavorful. Salmon sandwich was delicious. Dining room look can be deceiving because most people are probably in the beautiful patio in back. Menu has tons of options and worth exploring.
author: Rob K.

description: Previously I have only wandered into S&G for brunch (awesome) - today we stopped in to check out the dinner menu. Surprisingly diverse menu ranging from French onion soup to pad Thai. Good choice for the group today.
author: Ali A.

description:
Sauce & Gobble.

Excellent house BBQ sauce. Sweet. Tangy. Five stars.

Perfect as part of their grilled chicken, corn and caramelized onion crepe. Appreciated the choices of fries, fruit or salad on the side.

Table service even though you order at the counter. Subtle heat lamps enable you to sit outside and enjoy the free WiFi even in slightly chilly November weather.

A strong three stars held back only by the ten dollar price. Not crazy expensive, but could have been a buck or two lower based on the not overwhelming portion size.

Or perhaps you're just investing in the sauce.
author: Jason B.

description:
I went here for a quick lunch on Mother's Day. Mom was not with me. Same on me, I know. This is a spot that I've seen in passing but never stopped in just because I was on my way to anywhere else. So I finally stopped in.

The service is fast casual and the menu is written on a chalkboard above the line. I like this homey and casual touch. It's a neighborhood place after all. The service was polite and they were accommodating as I remember seeing a tiny server moving a large table from one end of the dining room to the other after accommodating a larger party. The food, however, is lacking a little bit. Mostly due to seasoning. Wll, lack thereof. I ordered a breakfast burrito with chorizo and my girlfriend had the veggie bendict sans hollandaise. 

The burrito seemed uneven in distribution of stuff. For me, when I have chorizo, I love the oil. The greasy, spicy, garlic that oozes into everything is the reason I love chorizo. I would use it for salad dressing and to make puff pastry for savory treats is I could ever stop sopping it up with warm tortillas and my fingertips. Sadly, for me, the burrito did not have this sexy oil. It was bland and egg heavy. I get it, it's a breakie burrito. Eggs are the main ingredient. But not my taste.

The veggie bennie (spinach florentine) was fine. For me I liked that they used bloomsdale spinach instead of baby. It has more flavor and the heartier stems give it some character. I know that my chefs all wanted me to pick off the stems since they're "inedible," but screw it. I think they're lovely. My girlfriend was in the same court as my chefs however. To each their own I guess. But this, too, needed some seasoning.
author: Jay V.

description:
I would love to give a 4 even a 5... but.. always a but...
Service is slow... how can only one server/order taker be scheduled in the morning... especially after The Grove closed across the street.  It is always busy.  The waiter/cashier just has too much to do... the phone, the orders, making drinks, serving food,... I could go on... oh sure it gets done, but lacks.  And sometimes my eggs come out cold since no one was able to run them out.  They always seem to be scrambling.. no egg pun intended!  It is not from lack of trying, the guys are moving.. they just need another person... I must add ...5 stars to the busperson who helps out in the mornings during the week,   so wonderful and helpful!
Food tasty... crepes, eggs, bacon.. but... there's that but again...fruit side is always a bit smooshy and definitely could be fresher, tastes usually like yesterdays... not the day before, but yesterdays.
author: Kallie K.

description: Must order Belgium waffle!!! Best waffle I've ever eaten. Comes with fruit and whipped cream, it crispy and light, amazing! Croissant Sandwich is delicious as well, eggs are perfectly cooked. Potatoes have a delicious rosemary flavor. We found out after we were already seated that there is a back patio, will definitely try it out next time!
author: Alissa S.

description:
Something is up with this place.  I used to go here at least 2x/month for weekend brunch, but service has gone downhill in a HURRY (see other recent posts).  Got there on Sunday, place was maybe half full if that.  Waited 15 min in line to order (there were only 2 groups ahead of us).  After 25 minutes, we asked a waiter about our order.  He didn't come back.  We flagged another girl at 30 minutes.  She never came back.  Food arrives 38 minutes after ordering it.  At this point we've been in the place for almost an hour without eating and my young daughter was OVER it.  When we told the waitress we needed our food boxed because somehow it took almost 40 minutes to make SALAD, she was barely apologetic.  We'll go elsewhere or choose another location until we hear they've upped their game.  

Anywhere you order at the counter needs to bring your food within 15 minutes or else why bother?
author: Megan j.

description:
OK so what if the ambience is a tad corporate?
The latte was delicious -- well-foamed and generously portioned.
The service was prompt and friendly.
The free WiFi was up and operational.
Does that make me an old coot for appreciating this stuff?
author: Lisa T.

description:
We had just finished a training run for the Nike Womens marathon on the marina green and decided to find a place to eat close by. I knew we were close to Chestnut St, so we grabbed the first available parking spot and walked around looking for a good breakfast/brunch spot.

Man, I love the city, but geezeness a quarter per 10 minutes for the parking meters?!? Holy Cow!  Highway robbery! Goodness gracious! 

Anyways, saw this spot for crepes and all. We figured it must be good since it's packed with people....and they have other locations...

I ordered the chicken pesto crepe, my bf ordered the ahi tuna sandwich, my friend jenny ordered an omelete. I was a little disappointed that my crepe did not come with potatoes AND salad, since the menu said "rosemary potatoes OR salad."  OR?! Oh my goodness!  I can't have both? The potatoes were a little dry and so was the chicken in my crepe.  It was OK. I prefer the Tuscan Chicken of Crepevine better (may be cuz the chicken isn't as dry and there are mushrooms in it).

My boyfriend said his Ahi tuna sandwich was a little over cooked.

I have to mention that his ahi tuna was a FAT piece of tuna.  We were wondering how he'd eat it and that my crepe had a generous portion of chicken in it...although it was on the dry side.

Next time we're in the area, we might try the two other restaurants across the street. I cant remember the names (one was a cafe, one was on the corner). Seemed a lot of people were at eating both estabishments. Not sure if we were impressed enough to come back to this one.
author: Dawn D.

description:
We were on Chestnut on the hunt for a quick brunchy kinda place. Perfect since they serve breakfast and lunch items, and crepes.  I had the salmon sandwich on focaccia with the potatoes.  Oh my gosh....one of THE best rosemary roasted potatoes I've had. I could've eaten that alone and been satisfied!  The salmon sandwich was a great accompaniement to the potatoes! ;)  

My friends had the Baby Spinach Salad and the Fillmore Omelette.  Everyone enjoyed what they ordered and the portions were very generous.  You order at the counter but one of their waitstaff brings your order to you.  And they come around to refill your drinks and warm up your coffee.  We didn't expect full service when we first walked in. Another star in my book.

Next time I eat here, I'm ordering a crepe!
author: Anna R.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by this crepery! The Hawaiian crepe with ham, cheese, pineapple and sweet and sour sauce was really quite good. The crepe came with your choice of potatoes or fruit. The fruit salad was a generous portion considering it was a side. My friend also really enjoyed the Eggs Benedict and home-style potatoes. Service was quick and efficient.
author: Marissa P.

description: The food was pretty good and the service was fast.  Only reason not a 5 is the server didn't know which omelet was which and the plates got mixed up in our group.
author: Kat N.

description: Consistently good food over a several year time period and the prices are still reasonable.  My asian chicken salad was a good size portion and wonderful.  The burger that my friend ordered was good too.  Skip the overpriced place across the street and enjoy a nice meal here.
author: Boris G.

description:
Wish I could give it 0 stars. New manager was openly yelling at staff in front of clients. And when I mean "yelling" i mean "YELLING" as in "you are a worthless piece of Sh*t!" Over changing a light bulb!  *gulp* that was my cue to walk out but friend insisted on staying. 

Staff actually advised us to write yelp reviews stating new managers abuse.   

Crystal ball indicates employee lawsuits in near future.
author: M B.

description:
I like this place.  It is a good alternative to my first choice for breakfast, The Grove Cafe, which is right across the street.  This place will be more packed with families with young kids, not so much at the Grove.  

Crepes are done well.  Coffee drinks (latte, cappuccino) done very nicely here.  Heartier breakfast fare such as egg dishes, scrambles are satisfying and will hold you to a late lunch.
author: Ellen o.

description:
Awesome brunch spot. Cute little patio in the back with a fountain too.

Love the egg dishes and crepes!
author: Julie V.

description:
This was my first time going to the Marina location, but it was perfect for a large group of us to mingle on New Years Eve.  I've been to their West Portal location and thought that was okay.  I was quick to observe its Marina-ish environment: Uppa Baby stroller in the corner, Bugaboo stroller in the other, Uggs on a baby, and there I was with the cheapo Graco.  

Anyway, the table took forever to be cleaned so that we could not even sit down for awhile.  There was water spilled all over the floor, sticky champagne glasses on the table.  Several tables needed cleaning and I'm wondering if it was because some of their staff took off for the holidays or if that's normal.  When we had one more guest arrive, his food took FOREVER to come.  We were all finished with our food and had to sit and wait.    I noticed several other tables waiting for a long time looking bored.  

When the food finally came, it was good.  My cobb salad was really tasty with chunks of avocado and egg and there was plenty of food to split on one plate.  A side salad was good enough for people who were not extremely hungry.  I have eaten their crepes before and I like those as well.

Ironically, when I turned on the TV a day later, Jay Leno was doing his Headlines and when he came across a sign that said "Squat and Gobble," he laughed hysterically.  I didn't laugh as hard as he did.  Hey, it's a local place.  We're used to the name.
author: Stacey C.

description: Great atmosphere, decent prices, great coffee, and largest/tastiest croissant sandwich I have ever had. Come here!
author: Jenne S.

description:
Seriously, I need to stop eating at all their sister stores- Crepevine and Crepeville- because it's the same type of items on the menu.  Don't get me wrong...I love their food...I should venture out to different places when I go out to eat.  

The 1/2 sandwich combo was a good balance- 1/2 turkey gobble on toasted grain bread, with garlic potatoes, and a small green salad.  Very filling, but it wasn't so much that it made me overly stuffed.  My friend ordered the small Caesar salad, but when it came out, we both swore it was a large...it was ginormous! 

Love the Marina location because it was very spacious & clean, with a very nice staff.  Plus, it's right across from the Grove Cafe and down the street from Kara's Cupcakes..both of which we made a stop at.
author: Lisa C.

description: 5 Stars. The bomb. Hungover as a mug on a Saturday. Im from San Jose so I was in the same clothes as the night before as I crashed on my homies couch. (just painting the picture of the experience.)  Wow. This place blew my mind. I have some kind of California crepe but with Salmon. so bomb. so delicious.  the coffee- I had to ask where they get it from as it was European strong and super flavorful. The waiter was beyond on it. white guy, skinny, 5'8 ish blonde hair. FoHawk. My coffee and water never got below 3/4 full. Everyone was so nice and friendly. Also a big ass little league parade went down Chestnut while we sat outside and enjoyed the show. top 5 breakfasts I have had in my life. I will force my friends to return there as I currently refuse to try anywhere else until they prove me wrong. oh and I almost lost my mind over the home style potatoes.
author: Warren K.

description:
The definition of "meh", or perhaps more accurately, "the Grove was packed so we walked across the street". Squat & Gobble has an expansive menu, which is great, but my visit there this weekend left a lot to be desired.

We had a group of 5, and though we were paying separately we were told that we had to be rung up by the same cashier, in order to ensure that our orders were on the same ticket and arrived together. Good call, S&G...this makes total sense. Unfortunately, it proves to be utterly pointless.

Our drinks (mimosas for the gals, beers for the guys, natch) came out one by one, a few minutes apart. Kind of strange. After 10 minutes, my omelette emerged. No one else was even acknowledged. 5 minutes later, my friend's breakfast came. We then waited for 20 minutes for the other 3 people to have their food delivered, even after flagging down a server and asking him to check on it (he never returned with an update). Eventually a manager dropped the food off without an actual apology. So two of us had cold breakfast, 3 of us were annoyed, and the staff was unhelpful. Not impressed.
author: Kelly B.

description: This neighborhood is so enjoyable especially during brunch time!!! Squat and Gobble has to be one of my favorite spots in the cityfor breakfast time especially because they serve it anytime! I love their delicious hot chocolate and their own whip cream, its so light, yum! The belgian waffles are also good but the french toast is so memorable because the bread that they use is so thick and distinct. I also ordered a side of bacon which is never disappointing. Squat and Gobble has much to choose from besides breakfast options (they serve great lunch and dinner) then those than the ones I have mentioned, so this place is worth stopping by.
author: C M.

description:
We went here for breakfast and mimosas, and everything was pretty good. But left something to be desired.

The orange juice is fresh-squeezed, which sounds great until you happen to go on a day when the oranges are sour... The guy at the counter got my order wrong (I got crab cakes florentine and potatoes instead of the eggs florentine and fruit that I ordered), but I am not picky so I ate it anyway. The rosemary breakfast potatoes are really tasty, but I think they should use thinner crab cakes because that dish was too vertical and unwieldy, and the crab a little overpowering.

I'd go back again to try the crepes, but I'd look elsewhere for other breakfast fare.
author: Benjamin M.

description:
As a local living in the neighborhood, SnG used to be my "go-to" spot in the Marina. I was one of the first customers and regulars when it opened. It was my favorite place for a meeting over a meal.

The place is still good: free wi-fi, comprehensive menu, comfortable seating, consistently food quality, great location, plus an awesome back patio for sunny days, and friendly service. And I'd still recommend SnG on a sunny day and for friends coming to town -- their back patio  is still the sunniest, protected spot on Chestnut. But better to go outside "meal times" if you don't want to fight the crowds.

But sadly things have changed, and it's been at the expense of some longtime customers like me. I always thought SnG's differentiator was a unique approach to the Marina business crowd... they used to have open power outlets, which they've covered up. It used to be a place where local professionals could eat, work and hang all day  -- and invite people to meet them, work, and then share meals. SnG had a cafe culture all its own. It supported nomadic workers and local software developers. Simply: was a nice clean professional place to get shit done. 

Now it's a pricey omelette at $10, given the other close by options. My favorite thing at SnG -- business friendly approach -- is no more. But still a great place for a sunny chat on a weekend..
author: Jared K.

description:
The food is totally average. I love crepes, but this place makes nothing all that special. The venue is nice, so that merits something. 

It's a great neighborhood place, and always busy- particularly for weekend brunch and day-time lunch. They do have a nice patio and great salads, but all in, it's nothing to write home about. The brunch is really good and the portions of all food is big enough to share.
author: Jennifer K.

description: So many great affordable options! They serve breakfast food all day and the lunch/dinner options were awesome too. You definitely get a good sized portion for the price you pay. The omelets are awesome and the grilled salmon Cobb is incredible. I frequent this place and I highly recommend it.
author: Alyssa D.

description:
Recommended! The food is great (especially the salmon focaccia that my wife ordered. I had the Reuben, which was also good.) Plus, there's plenty of seating; even with a huge line for ordering, nobody was waiting on tables.

The only major drawback is that the serving team and/or the kitchen crew seemed pretty understaffed - we waited for at least 20 minutes for the food.

It was worth it, though!
author: Andrew M.

description: 3-1/2 stars really. And only because I'm giving the other location on Haight/Ashbury a 4-star rating , as I prefer that location better than this. Kitchen is a bit different, I believe but food isn't bad at all here. Will come back only if hungry and in the area :-)
author: Nick R.

description:
We are newbies to SF (in the process of relocating). After signing our lease on our new flat in the Richmond District, we decided to do some noshing. A couple of weeks ago, after biking from downtown to the Golden Gate, my husband popped in here. So, he decided let's eat here again.

Cute place. Yeah, you order at the counter then it is sorta full-service. My hubby ordered the blueberry pancakes, scrambled eggs and the chicken/apple sausage (same thing he had last time). I decided to have a more traditional dinner, for $19.99 you get an app, entree, and a glass of wine.

What was cool, is that they had quite a few choices for all 3 options. So, I decided on the soup of the day (tomato bread); the half chicken, mashers w/ mushroom wine gravy and the squash; and a glass of sauvignon blanc. The soup was quite tasty and rich. Not real sweet and nice spice to it. However, there were a few stems from the herbs which was odd.

Chicken was nicely seasoned, but a little overcooked and the bones broke a bit too easily. Mushroom gravy was nice, 'taters were good, but tasted like they had Gorgonzola in them (not a huge fan of the latter). The squash was nicely done, but I don't like squash much, unless it is grilled.

Hubby's pancakes were tasty and the sausage is nice (as long as you are not hoping for traditional breakfast pork links). 

What was most impressive about this meal, the amount of food was huge. After the soup, I was not that hungry and only ate a small portion of entree (did the rest as take away... always fun taking leftovers on the BART back to Oakland).

We are used to Austin-area prices in Texas for food, and it's funny I cannot recall, in the 14 years that I have lived there, having a meal of this caliber (not super nice but decent) w/ a glass of wine for $20. Love it!

We will likely be back when down in the Marina or check other locations that are closer to our new digs when we are here perm starting in Sept.
author: Melissa W.

description: Good brunch food, great patio in the back for days when it's sunny. A good staple, but nothing extraordinary.
author: Vitaliy D.

description:
I am still in shock about an experience my friends and I had at the Marina Squat and Gobble over the weekend...
 
We came in for Sunday brunch and sat on the back patio. It was a good group, nice day, and everything was great until we realized 30 minutes had gone by and some of us were still waiting for beverages (long after the food had arrived). My friend had finished her entire meal and was still waiting on a soda. The waitress stopped by several times, as did the manager, and each time we were assured the soda was coming. It didn't. Even as tray after tray of drinks came for other tables....Finally, on the waitress's umpteenth visit, my friend said, "Any chance I can get that soda finally? It's been 30 minutes and you keep saying it's coming..." The waitress assured us her manager was bringing it, and we returned to our conversation. 
 
Two minutes later the manager - mid thirties, dark hair, goatee, storms over (SANS SODA, I might add) and berates us for upsetting his server so much that she started to cry. He iniststed they were doing their best, and our rudeness was completely uncalled for. Um, what?? You are yelling at a group of customers for asking - not yelling, not swearing - for a drink they paid for and expected half an hour ago? My friend apologized for upsetting the server, but he kind of brushed it off and was standoffish for the rest of our visit, which wasn't long.
 
We were a mixed group of mostly girls in our mid twenties, and we are polite and friendly people with experience in the service industry. I have to wonder if the manager would have yelled at a group of guys, or a group of thirty- or forty-somethings...?? 
 
It's too bad, because the food and atmosphere are both great, not to mention the location. In any event - we won't be back.
author: Janice E.

description: Very mediocre food. Too many good places on Chestnut. If you're feeling in the mood for something commercial this is your stop. The people are plenty nice. The format is great. The food lacks any pop on a street filled with options.
author: Nelson C.

description:
5 stars for having a great name....which my friends and I decided could very easily be condensed to The Squabble :D

-1/2 star for having such an expansive menu board.  I'm hungover and hurting.  I do not have the wherewithal to stare up at a board with bright colors and lots of text.  Too much text.  Break it down for me.  Simplify.  Print and laminate some menus that I can hunker over while I wait in line to place my order.

-1/2 star for not having a full wait staff.  Serve me!  

-1 star for calling a short stack of buttermilk pancakes topped with blueberry compote "blueberry pancakes."  That's crap and you know it.  When I wake up hungover and start quoting Pulp Fiction, I'm not in the mood for pancakes saturated in sweet, blue goop.  Would you throw a pile of chocolate chips on top of a short stack and call them "chocolate chip pancakes?"  I think not!

On the up side...
The bacon was thick and delicious - extra crispy, like I ordered it!
The coffee was strong!
The orange juicer took me back to my trips to Espana (nostalgia points!)
The staff were very gracious about my friend's special request for honey and soy milk for her coffee.
The hot coffee flowed like water.

Would I go back?  Yes!  That massive menu board needs to be taught a lesson!
author: Patricia O.

description:
I have eatten at several of Squat and Gobble locations, but tonight I wasn't quite hungry.  Plenty of open tables in this restaurant, just wanted to spend an hour on my laptop.

Something does not feel right here.  I came here instead of the Grove tonight across the street because sometimes the internet reception is better.

Tonight at first I just ordered a lemonade.  One of the guys who took my order seemed annoyed or disturbed that that was all I was ordering.  

When I ordered a coffee later, the service was not exactly more receptive/friendly.

Another dude here, and gal seem very sweet.

Alas, maybe I am not having the best day, but it's amazing how one person can ruin things for ya. 

I am not a crepe fanatic anyways, but I don't think I want to return here.
author: Alanna F.

description: I am a huge fan of Squat & Gobble and have eaten there many times, mostly at the West Portal location, and a couple times at the one on Haight St.   I have always had exceptional service, food is always great!  Staff very friendly with smiles.  Unfortunately this morning was not a good experience when a friend and I decided to have breakfast last minute at this location.   Our first choice was Home Plate on Lombard, great place, but a long wait time.  At S&G my receipt showed 9:54am, unfortunately we didn't get our food until 10:35.   Just to add there was no line with only a customer ahead of us.  Our food was okay with the exception of my french toast was very dry.  Another funny thing is that we asked the waitress can she check on our order and she says what's our table # which was on the table.   Several minutes later we see her going outside with our food, two plates, only one customer outside.   I tell my friend, I think that's our order?  Didn't she asked us what are table # was??   Sure enough it was.  I was too annoyed/upset to complain and just wanted to leave.   I have met the owners several times in the past, great people, will always highly recommend S&G, just this one bad experience tells me I'm not going back to this location again.
author: Glenn A.

description:
I used to come here a lot for crepes and they're decent, just the standard crepes served at every Squat & Gobble. Recently, I came here to order a half chicken caesar salad because I had the urge to chomp on some greens and they give pretty big portions. To my surprise, as I started to eat my salad back at work, I noticed a weird fishy taste in my salad and searched around to find two pieces of this mysterious greyish-brown slithers of I'm guessing fish (since it reeked of it). I also found some tortilla chip crumbs in my salad.

I was thoroughly disgusted and lost my appetite. Sorry, but you lost my business for sure..  I'd rather to go to the one in West Portal.
author: Helen Z.

description:
this place really needs to update the quality of its food and interior!!! 

i was on an outing with my parents and looking for something quick and simple to eat. thinking chestnut st. is full of wonderful restaurants how bad could it be. walked in to this dilapidated space with a garbage like odor. i tried to stay optimistic,cause iv been to "holes in the wall" that honestly make amazing food.
 my mother ordered the salmon sandwich witch had soggy lettuce the piece of salmon tasted as if it had been frozen then thawed out then frozen again with slimy pickles on the side that resembled banana slugs.
my father ordered the beef and noodles witch came so piping hot from a microwave it was as if  it  came straight from a volcano not to mention the beef it self was so old it had that spoiled beef taste,then they tried to mask the flavor by adding a tone of red Thai chilies.
i ordered the sea food linguine. it came with muscles shrimp and clams. the muscles were so dried out they were separating from the shell and had that dark orange color they only get when left out for hours.  the shrimp was water logged and tasted of mildew or wet socks!  the clams were clearly from a can as well.
with living in such a culinary driven city there is really no excuse for the lack of quality in their food.
this is their opportunity to take pride in their restaurant and costumers. hope they will!!!
author: Alana T.

description:
Not bad for Sunday brunch, but not stellar either.  The service was great.  We were seated outside and the servers struck just the right balance of attentiveness and letting us hang out undisturbed.

Latte was decent.  I got the lox omelet.  First, the side potatoes were excellent and the omelet itself was cooked right (eggs are delicate, I know).  But the lox tasted like it had been sitting uncovered in the fridge long enough to get a little hard and crusted around the edges.

I live close enough that I will be back sometime to give it another chance (I've heard good things from friends)... but my experience this time was unremarkable.
author: N M.

description:
What used to be a casual, order at-the-counter and sit for bfast, lunch, or dinner place has morphed into a "We pretend to be an upscale semi-sit down service place, yet we're not.  We'll overcharge you for it, but the food's not that good."

The manager runs around being all strict about not letting you get your own water, and possesses an over-the-top saccharine manner.  He's very friendly, but his ultra efficient manner makes the place oddly unappetizing, like a factory.

Sure, it's a chain.
Yes, menu has a lot of choices, which seems good, but nothing gets done really well, except some breakfast items.  And fresh squeezed orange and grapefruit juice.

I've had the pasta (half was oozing oil, the other half was semi-cooked giant pieces of onion), gobble sandwich (pretty tasty, though the bread seasoning is overdone and stays with you all day), and fried seafood appetizer (grossly greasy).
author: Bamboo T.

description:
I have never been a fan of this place...but met a group of friends that were craving their pancakes...so I went along for the ride.

Note to Squat and Gobble - if someone orders the eggless tofu scramble, I"m "guessing" they are trying to eat healthy. So why oh why did you have to dump an entire pound of butter on the scramble???? Not even edible, It was literally forming a pool around my plate.

Needless to say I ended up across the street at the grove after my meal because I was still hungry. 

2 stars because the manager came over and brought me a 2nd mimosa and I didn't have to wait in line!
author: Wendy W.

description:
i really love this spot!  the staff are all incredibly friendly, helpful, and seem to know who their regulars are (points to self).  i've had a variety of items on the menu and it's all been delicious.  the chicken sandwich here is probably my favorite chicken sandwich ever.  the pesto, cheese, and arugula certainly help push it over the top.  i've been on a real ceasar salad kick lately and theirs is superb.  with a bit of grilled chicken on top and dressing on the side (i like to moderate my use of such a deep flavored dressing), it's a filling lunch that i sometimes crave a few times a week.  

parking on Chestnut St can be a bit of a pain, but parking off of the main street is usually easier.
author: Anjanette M.

description: While the food was good enough the service was ridiculous. We ordered at the counter where they had various baked goods in cake stands. With my husbands breakfast we asked for a croissant on the side. I paid for breakfast which was $57 and seemed steep for two entrees, two coffees, and a mimosa but no receipt was provided so I could not check to confirm. When the food came out (no drinks delivered yet), there was my entree, my husbands, and a croissant breakfast sandwich. I looked at it and said "that's not ours," and pointed to the breakfast platter that was and said, "but that is." The waiter responded with "come on guys," in the rudest tone ever suggesting we were not sure what we ordered. I went inside to the counter and said that they delivered a breakfast sandwich and clearly over charged us, the man taking orders was also beyond rude and told me that you can't buy a croissant separately( yet here out on display?) and that when I asked for one he put what was on the menu. This could not be more ridiculous because if that was true, why did he not ask me how I wanted the eggs cooked on said requested sandwhich. The drinks came out 15 minutes after the food and I had to ask 5 different serves for my mimosa in the end going up to the counter an standing there till it was handed to me, while my food got cold. This was some of the poorest service I have encountered and I am so disappointed, I am upset I ever paid $45 in the end for servers to be that rude. Do not go here unless you want your servers to treat you like a child
author: Samantha M.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE the staff here they are all super nice and helpful and just AMAZING.  The food is also fantastic and you are able to share plates  because they give you so much!  The portabella mushroom sandwich is amazing and the house salad is great as well as the salmon salad!!  The secret garden in the back is such a hidden treasure and they have heat lamps, so don't let the name scare you away its worth your wild!!!
author: Hillary B.

description:
I've had different experiences every time I've come here.

1st visit: Service was slow...there were 6 in my party and 2 people didn't get served until we were all finished. They sat there teary eyed with hunger.

2nd visit: Service was much better, however the home style potatoes we received you could tell had been sitting there for a while they were heavy and super oily. Not even ketchup could help them.

3rd visit: Above average service, but took a while to receive our food and the place was pretty empty. Seemed like the cooks were slackin.

Asian Chicken Salad - very good
Italian Crepe w/potatoes - very good
Salmon and cheese omelette - mushy
Grilled Chicken Sandwich on Foccacia - good
Steamed Mussels - good
Veggie Crepe - good
author: Michelle Y.

description: This place was recommended by a friend for a good breakfast place. I was a bit disappointed in our food. The crepe was much too thick for my taste. My husband's omelette with lox had large chucks of oddly textured salmon. Not exactly what we were hoping for. The wait staff was very friendly and attentive though. There's a nice outdoor patio in the back for seating, which I would recommend over the inside ripped plastic covered chairs.
author: Shana K.

description:
This is a good reliable brunch place when you wake up at noon on the weekends and are craving an omelet, crepe, waffle, pancake.. etc. They have a very good assortment of brunchy, breakfast, lunch dishes to choose from, and the interior is cute and comfortable. 

I've tried the lower pac heights omelet w/ egg whites, and the veggie tofu egg white scramble. I always replace my side of potatoes with a fruit salad, which they're happy to accommodate. We've also gotten their dessert crepes (which can't really be BAD), and I'm interested to see how the savory ones are.
