I've yet to try any of their lunch items, like sandwiches or salads, but from scoping out other ppl's food, they look yummy. 

Their mango cocktail is good too if anyone wants to get their day jumpstarted. Overall I like this place, but I'm not totally in love with it. There are plenty of its kind around the city, i.e. Crepe House, that offer good staple brunch items on a leisurely day.
author: Natalie W.

description: Atmosphere was nice, friendly service, food was decent. Nice place to meet up with folks and have a casual brunch.
author: Eric T.

description:
I absolutely LOOOOVE this place!!!  Whenever I come here, I always order something new on the menu.  They have the best breakfast ever!!!  

This place is a must go for all foodies!!!!!
author: Jes D.

description:
this s&g is cool, but they can improve their customer service. There was one night when I went with AT and their card machine broke, and so I had to walk all the way across the street to get it fixed and on top of that when I got back this woman in front of me couldn't decide what they wanted to eat for a looong time and all the waiters were standing around and couldn't even open up another cashier until the people started to line up. 
But the food was okay,it could of been a bit better. And I love how they fresh squeeze their og. mmm. AT loves their house potatoes but there wasn't enough for him. They have good ravioli but it's to creamy, it was like eating pho, noodle and soup and then at the end theres no more noodles and just SOUP. The cream was like SOUP, except very thick. He's such a fan everywhere we go he looks for S&G.
author: Carolyn Y.

description: Back patio Is beautiful, very cute little place with great food and great drinks!
author: Michael L.

description:
This place has the BEST healthy take-out...so awesome. Their salads are made with really fresh ingredients and the proteins are super high quality. J'adore their Mexican Chicken Salad and Asian Chicken Salad because you can tell that they literally just grilled the chicken breast for you on the spot when they add it to your salad or sandwich. 

Unlike Pluto's down the street that has meh, hit-or-miss meat that can really ruin your dish...

Okay, also - their back patio? So cute! For what is essentially supposed to be a quick, dash and dine type place where you can eat for $10 a person, the patio has heat lamps, a striped awning that they put up on cold nights, strings of white lights, burbling fountains and legit tables that make you feel like you can actually relax and not rush out (again, Pluto's comes to mind...).

YAY, I'm so happy to have discovered this neighborhood gem! The service is friendly, the choices plentiful, and it never seems to be overly crowded.
author: Britt M.

description:
The food is ok!!
VERY CAREFUL with your BiLL not on the time later in your account!!
They charged more than I have in my ticket I wrote back for their but they didn't write back to me I didn't receive my money back or one SIMPLE I am sorry about THAT!! May the tip I gave was not enough!!
author: Bertina r.

description: My food came out cold and my GF got the wrong order. Management failed to resolve the issue.
author: Ryan O.

description:
After walking the Marina for a while yesterday we needed something savory and tasty. I ordered their beef melt, but what I got wasn't food. It was akin, in both texture and flavor, to the slop you find in the dark crevice between the oven and the deep fryer of a busy restaurant. The lemongrass dressing on the side salad had the texture of cold gravy and tasted just as appealing. The greens were fresh and crisp, though.
When I got the leftovers of my mushy, gray, overpriced sandwich home, my roomie promptly criticized me for even stepping foot in this joint. Apparently those who know the area know to stay away.
I KNEW we should have gone to Chilayo! Oops.
author: C S.

description:
Really good - HUGE menu. You can pretty get whatever you want for brunch/lunch here - omelettes, salads, sandwiches, pasta, bagels...the list goes on! 

I had the Fresh Tomato Mozzarella Salad which was really good - great dressing! My friend ordered the Grilled Chicken Sandwich and that was really delicious as well. 

It's a little hard to find seating if you go at peak times on the weekend but there's a pretty fast turnover so you wouldn't have to wait too long.
author: Jeanette L.

description: Make sure you sit on the back patio!  It' has an amazing atmosphere to go along with the great food and quick service.  Everything is fresh, tasty and comes in large quantities.  You'll be sure to enjoy!
author: Joe S.

description:
So goooooooooooooooooooooodddddddddddddddddd!!! Shrimp with angelhair pasta is soooooooooooooooo my new favorite!!!! and their crab melt might give you the b.g.'s but so freaking worth it.

advice : even though you can probably eat your whole serving, don't do it!!!! crack kills!! hahahahah and they have their own coffee :) delish!!!!
author: Nina M.

description: This is a very reliable breakfast spot. I had the Nor Cal omelet and really enjoyed it. It's extremely healthy, lots of veggies, although they put perhaps a bit too much sour cream sauce all over it. But this is a good place to drop in for a quick meal, they also have some seating outdoors on the sidewalk for nicer days.
author: One T.

description:
Everything is delish about the place! 

They serve your all american breakfast if your craving for that.

Crepes! they have a good selection of them when it comes to a desert format or meal.
 
My friend once told me there is something about the Coke at this place coke as in soda. I tried it out and it does taste different, GOOD different! 

It does get really pack here especially in the weekends. 

Very clean location.
author: Conchita B.

description:
The name of this place cracks me up.  In reality, it's not much different from Crepevine.  Food was good - but I was hoping for an omelet with the apple chicken sausage in it, but didn't see it on the menu.  Ended up with a Triple 'something'.  Apple chicken sausage, eggs, and buttermilk pancakes.  YUMMY!  My non-fat mocha hit the spot as well.  Hubby had a chicken gobble sandwich.  I didn't try it - looked like a club sandwich to me.  I guess it was good because there wasn't a crumb left.  Came with GREAT roasted potatoes that I had to help myself to.  

Sat outside and enjoyed the beautiful weather - something we usually never do in SF because it's too chilly.  Perfect day to enjoy the outdoors today.
author: Denise M.

description:
Let me say, I'm morally opposed to eating somewhere called "Squat" anything.  However, after hearing good things I was dragged into this joint.

The cleanliness wasn't up to par, but apparently I'm "ocd" about how clean I like things, especially in places where I eat.  (This should be normal, but whatever.)

The people working here were difficult to communicate with.

The food was not good.  And by not good, I mean bad.  It was greasy and old tasting (I had the grilled chicken sandwich)...  

If you *have* to eat here, get a salad.  Thank me later.
author: Jess S.

description:
Nice spacious place, loved their patio.
Food was ok, Service was good. They were not too busy on Friday at 6PM so we got a good table too.
author: Zeba S.

description: It's a good place for brunch, with a nice outside patio. Food is average, as well as selection of drinks. It's a reasonable choice. although not a top one.
author: Steve E.

description:
Wow!  That's all I can say....

I'm not a SF resident, but this place makes me wish I was!  We had breakfast here at 10am on a Saturday morning, and I was shocked that we would even find a seat.  The food and drink is a little pricey, but it's totally worth it.  The OJ is so fresh (and so clean), I wanted to buy a juicer on our way back to Santa Cruz!!!  The food was intensely rich, and the coffee was excellent.  Will come again when spending the night in SF.
author: Courtney R.

description:
I've only been here once, and I'm not a local, so it may be a while before I get the chance to return. Anyway, when I was there I tried the "french toast indulgence", which LOOKS amazing. I don't remember what exactly is in the filling, but I do remember something about Italian cream or something. Upon tasting it, everything was good EXCEPT the filling. I liked the first bite, but after that it just tasted like molasses, cinnamon, and cream cheese. Ew! All that for around just under $10? No thanks. My friends each got different things; one got pancakes that she was very happy with, and the other got a breakfast burrito that looked amazing! (it's on a special menu board right under what I got, and seems to have pretty much everything in it!) If I get the chance to come back, I would like to try the burrito....without chorizo, of course.
My friend who ordered the pancakes also got a Screwdriver (I'd like to mention that they squeeze their orange juice fresh, and everything that contains OJ has fresh-squeezed in it....definitely a plus) but this drink tasted like a floral perfume might taste. I've never had a screwdriver before, so idk if they all taste that way, but it was really nasty.

If you go, I recommend sitting on the covered (and heated!) patio. It's a nice atmosphere, takes you away from the crowded front area, and has vines and fountains and stuff. Even the little bathroom is neat, and has tile that looks like grass. 

I can't say I had a BAD experience, but I would certainly order something other than the french toast indulgence, as I had better stuffed french toast at IHOP.
author: Devin H.

description:
When I used to live in the Marina I would come here all the time.  The salads are my go-to meals here.  All the salads come in big portions and pretty delicious.  I don't remember ever having a bad salad here.  The service is also pretty good.  

What's great about this place unlike Judy's from across the street, is that here you don't feel like you're getting kicked out once you're done eatting.  You can actually sit, eat, relax, and talk with your friends.  Pretty awesome place I would say.
author: Annie S.

description:
3.5 Stars :) 

First of let me tell you about S&G most friendly, helpful, & hardworking server Liz...She goes way beyond the call of duty.  Her excellent service truly deserves recognition.  In one of our conversations she even recommended a clean, legit massage place that offers 1hr for $20.

*Clean
*Kid Friendly
*Great Outdoor Patio Seating
*Good food
*Recommendations:
Crab Cakes Florentine (my favorite), Pork Chop w/ maple glazed sweet potatoes, & Sweet Crepes.

This has become my go-to place for a great taste & great value! Throw away your preconceived judgments about this place. They don't only have Crepes and Breakfast food!
author: Christina D.

description:
My bff and I came to brunch here this past weekend. We were gonna eat somewhere else, but it was closed so we found Squat and Gobble. Like another yelper said, I wasn't sure what to expect, but I found the name quite amusing. I said it a few times over just to get a chuckle.

When we first walked in, the lady taking our order was very friendly. Most of the staff was all smiles. 

Anywho, it was a beautiful Saturday afternoon. We sat in the back patio area right by the fountain, not too sunny and not too shady. It was perfect. We were gabbing over our early mid-life crises, enjoying an eggs florentine and a crab salad.  I had a bite of the crab salad. Very fresh, but it had cilantro in it and I'm not a fan of cilantro - so a bite was all I had. 

I ordered the eggs florentine and it comes with either a salad or potatoes. The eggs florentine was delish. Everything about it was just great. The runny egg, crispy English muffin, just the right amount of cheese (at least I think there was cheese) and lots of spinach. Mmmmm.  The salad was just a salad, nothing amazing and nothing horrible. It just was. 

I want to go back to try the crepes and sandwiches. I was eyeballing these dishes at other people's tables.
author: Dolores L.

description: Upping my review to five stars. The entire team is bend-over-backwards friendly, helpful and nice. I go here regularly and they have made me feel nothing but welcome. each visit.  There have been some cool Asian-inspired additions to the menu that are worth checking out.
author: Angela N.

description:
Decent crepes. We were there for a Sunday brunch and it was extremely crowded.
All in all, it was your pretty run-of-the-mill crepe place in SF.
author: Paolo B.

description:
It started off poorly at the pluckily named Squat & Gobble. The registers were down and management was putzing around with the machine for about 15 min.  I would have left, but where else could I have squat and gobbled? During the whole delay the staff did their best to remain friendly and attentive. Smiles for everyone!

While waiting for the food, and waiting a little bit longer I had a chance to take in the decor.  I'm not sure what I was expecting from a place with such a name, and yet I was still surprised.  The decor seemed straight out of a catalog.  Not that it's tasteless or bad, but I suppose a little more character would have been nice. 

The food was nothing spectacular but still pretty good.  Granted I had the turkey burger, but it was better than others I've had.  And had I known there was a back patio, I would be telling you how that was. Should have come to yelp first.  Damn spontaneity.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. I mean, the name alone brings a smile to my face. Unfortunately, after eating here, my initial impression was - DO OVER. Meaning, I wish I could have a do over and not pick this place. 

I went with my boyfriend in hopes of having a delicious breakfast. The location was quite crowded, which seemed to be a good sign. We both ordered crepes and this was the mistake. Unfortunately, they were too heavy and the flavor just wasn't there. I've had quite a few good tasting crepes and this one did not even come close. I literally felt gross after eating there. Maybe there other foods are better but I probably won't be going back. Overall, the experience was disappointing.
author: Esther J.

description: I usually LOVE this place, however today was a less than stellar experience. First of all, it took so long to even place my order. It seemed that there was enough staff working, however only 1 person was taking orders from people in the extremely long line. Once I finally placed my order, I happily waited for my food (which I had to take to go since the wait to order took so long). I got my food but they forgot my coffee drink. Someone poured it for me and I was on my way. I got to work and opened my container, ready to dive in to my delicious breakfast meal! It smelled delicious and looked just as good as I remembered, however 1 very important ingredient was missing.... the eggs!!! I was craving breakfast and know that Squat and Gobbles always delivers on satisfying my craving, but today they forgot the eggs in my scrambled egg dish! I was so bummed. I just had to share so someone on staff can watch out for this. Also, all customers, check your meal before you leave when you get things to go!
author: Jenny P.

description:
Squat and Gobble, crowded and overpriced, represents everything that people dislike about the Marina. However, in the past few months there has been a huge shift for the positive. A previously inattentive staff now seems quick on the uptake. The back patio attendant now has an ear piece to communicate with the kitchen. Also, food seems to be coming out much quicker, which directly correlates with a decreased wait time for a table.

Their crepes and omelletes have the magical power to undo the damage done by last night's visit to Monoghan's. Lower Haight omelette with fruit please. Happy Hangover!
author: Rachael W.

description: The outdoor seating is perfect for my Match.com date!  My date was very impressed.  I got the Marina Crepe and would recommend to others.  My date got some nasty ass beans with eggs.
author: Doug F.

description: I do not normally go to small chain restaurants but Squat& Gobble breakfast was amazing. I highly recommend the NorCal and the Breakfast Burrito. Cannot wait to get back to San Francisco and go back for breakfast. My only comment would be for breakfast lovers; the food is amazing but you will pay probably about $17 for the meal and fresh orange juice. Based on the locations, atmosphere, friendly staff, and quality of the food I can justify a more expensive breakfast.
author: Tom F.

description:
Would like to try breakfast here. Walked in one afternoon and saw $4 Hef ( 20oz) . Of course I would like that. 

Split a mexican salad since we were here for a snack. 

Oh wait. You can't order that champagne cocktail on the menu. That's why I'm taking one star away. " We never serve that " He said. 

" You can NOT have that." Not a sensitve subject , just altogether bizarre. baby, you'll have to have the mimosa. " The juice is fresh squeezed". 

This is the only time I leave 15% and not 20 because you are ordering at the cashier, then sitting down. But you think I should change that just let me know. 

Back to the salad, I like the fact that I got a proper piece of grilled chicken, hate when it's minimal you know?

Need to run alongside Chrissy Field one morning and then peep an omlette, maybe even a crepe.
author: Taj A.

description:
I send my appreciation to the S&G for the free refills on regular coke and no hassle ordering process.  This location is clean, clean clean...and the special (steak and mashed taters) was exactly what I needed on day 2 of my post-Patron hangover weekend.  

Although, a crepe did not seem like an appetizing choice for me at the moment, the steak hit the spot.  That is one of the many things that I love about Squat & Gobble - CHOICES.  It is not just a breakfast place or a crepe place, they have other delectable things on their ever-expanding menu.  

My boyfriend chose the Hawaiian Crepe, and with the Special, I got a cup of potato and smoke salmon soup...DELISH.  

Total was approximately: $37 with tax and tip.
author: Hiromi N.

description: Not too shabby. I met a friend here for lunch on a Saturday, and the line wasn't really that bad considering it was brunch-time on Chestnut street. I ordered a lox, bagel, and cream cheese which is pretty standard everywhere, but it was tasty and it came out quickly. I will definitely be back here.
author: Holly G.

description:
This is my favorite breakfast spot. The menu has a great variety to choose from for breakfast.

It is so good I compare all other brunch/breakfast places to this standard and sadly finding this is very hard.

Good service, food comes out fairly quickly. The back patio is a must on a beautiful day.
author: Val F.

description:
I'm giving it two stars strictly for the pancakes.  I ordered them expecting a good-size stack for the price I'm paying, and I got three teeny pancakes that had to be "fanned" acrossed the plate to take up the space.  I was really craving pancakes, and this place didn't deliver.  Go to Crepevine instead.  

The salads are good and big though.
author: Neda B.

description:
if i could give a negative star - i would. maybe even a two negative stars.

after our saturday morning 5 mile run - came in for some grub. i heart squat & gobble in the castro, so one in the marina should be good too - right? well - that would be big fat NO.

got the asian chicken salad. good portions, good dressing, and why not throw in some plastic wrappers in there too. yep - found some plastic wrappers - nasty. told one of the server about it and he said "let me see what our manager says" - and that would be the last time i would see him.

there are so many great places to eat in the marina (on chestnut street nonetheless - so you need to be more than just a good portion place with some what average place to have your customer come back again and again.

with this shady food preparation - i am surprised that the manager didn't even bother to come by to say sorry. 

i would NEVER go back to this place and i would definitely warn my friends.

not to mention that i got sick from the contaminated salad.

be aware of what you eat at Squat & Gobble on Chestnut Street.
author: Dot K.

description:
On a beautiful sunny and chilly morning in the Marina district, my friend and I were in search of something hearty and tasty to help us start our day. We walked by a number of restaurants, but when we got to S&G, the menu looked yummy and we decided to go for it. 

Inside, it looks like a hippy's paradise cafe. Not TOO hippy, but it's got the vibe. You'll immediately notice the menu boards, in its fully vibrant chalky colors, confusing you with what you want to order. I didn't know what was tickling my tummy, so I asked the cashier what's good to try as a first-timer. He suggested the Gobble Club. So, I got that. 

Once seated, we waited for our food. I looked again some more and noticed the cafe had many mirrors. Are they superstituous? I didn't get an answer to that question, BUT our food arrived!  

The Gobble Club was deeelicious! Packed with BLT in a super-sized sandwich, this baby was very tasty! Add some delectable fruits and this was a great dish! 

The service was a bit slow, but in the end, they refilled our drinks continuously. Bon appetit at S&G!
author: Melinda L.

description:
I live in the Haight and have given the Squat and Gobble a couple of chances, because I wanted to like it, I really did. And I don't hate it, but I don't like it, either. All three times I've been in, I've had lukewarm (at best) service (and all the times I've been in have been off-peak times) and really truly mediocre food. 

Today, I ordered a burger with smoked gouda and avocado, medium rare with a side salad. The salad was great, superfresh nice dressing. The burger was forgettable; too rare (and I like my red meat pretty rare) forgotten avocado, and the cheese was slapped on top, not melted in the least. I had to ask three times for a refill on my diet coke, and twice for a to-go box.  

The Squat and Gobble is not awful, but it's not great. Will do if you're starving, but, if you're not, keep moving.
author: Emily M.

description: Wait was very long after ordering & paying for food.  Avoid the crab cake sandwich.  Lots of mayo and fillers and little crab.  Side potatoes arrived burnt.
author: Mirko P.

description: Great food. But slow service. We were the only people outside and the waiter was filling up the waters on the service table. didn't come over once. Drinks (coffee/OJ) didn't show up for 15 minutes right when we got our food.
author: Tyler S.

description: Good little place for a Bloody Mary breakfast with friends.  If you get there when it's not too busy, you can sit down and eat pretty well.  It's not too pricey for the area.  The menu is pretty basic.  Crepes add some nice diversity to the menu.  The timing was a little strange as two of us got our food, but it was 10 minutes until our friends got theirs.  It's high volume eating, but has some quality for what you're getting.  Honestly, I'd give it 3.5 if I could, but will give the extra star for a clean place and friendly service!
author: Andy S.

description: the staff was lovely but the food was horrible my burger was so dry and had no flavor what so ever my friend got the huervos rancherous with was disgusting so she exchanged it for a prime rib sandwich that wasn't any better and there were pigeons everywhere eating the leftover table scraps the staff didn't clear off, and the bathroom was a disgrace. I'M NEVER EATING THERE AGAIN.
author: Ally M.

description:
Twice I've had brunch in the Marina, and twice I have gone to this Squat and Gobble. The first time, they totally screwed up my Greek crepe order, and they were super slow and unapologetic about it. Not to mention that the crepe was watery and bland tasting. Meh. At least we got to sit outside. 

The second time, I had the 1/2 sandwich combo (eggplant, mozzarella, tomato, greens, lettuce on focaccia) with a salad and rosemary potatoes.  Ehhh, super salty, mushy sandwich on wimpyass, soggy focaccia. Rosemary potatoes don't taste very rosemaryish and are mealy, no crispiness here. The mixed green salad was ok, though their tart dressing leaves something to be desired. It's a decent amount of food though for $9. I suppose this isn't the most offensive food around, but it's not worth the trip out to the Marina. 

Best part of my meal? Sharing Kara's Cupcakes we had bought just before getting to S&G. Oh, and pointing out Muffy and Babs at the table next to us who looked like they were going to the Yacht Club after brunch. Next time I'm in the area, I'm going to skip the Squat and Gobble and go straight to the cupcakes.
author: Steph P.

description:
Its not amazing  but I will go here in a pinch. I dont find their crepes to be sensational by any means. In fact their dessert ones are pretty blah.

But I will give them credit for good sandos and hearty omelettes. I do enjoy their potatos, which Im amazed by how so many places screw that up! Ive tried their pasta too...not too shabby.

Back patio is nice and cant beat the location.
author: Heather S.

description: The mushroom ravioli was not bad but the service was terrible.  I wanted to try some garlic bread, so I ordered it to go.  My friend decided to order the ravioli to go after I ordered.  She got her order after half an hour wait (it was not busy at 4pm), and I didn't get my one piece of toast until after my friend go her order and I had to check on them twice.  There was no thank you or sorry for the long wait.
author: Julie Y.

description:
I come here pretty often as I live a short walk away and absolutely love to sit outside on the sidewalk tables and enjoy some of their great food.  

Today I have opted to write a review on this establishment because for the second time in a row I have dealt with a fairly unfriendly service person.  The last time I cam I figured, "We all have our off days" so maybe this gentleman was having an off day himself.  Today however, I brought a guest from out of town in for dinner and when she asked if the Salmon was wild, he quite rudely asked "Why does it make a difference?" and then continued on as how it shouldn't make a difference now because all of it was gonna end up farmed soon anyways!

As an overall review, the food is wonderful, the service is usually very good, the ambiance is great and prices are very affordable.  I would like to note that the face of the restaurant can strongly set the tone of a dining experience and it is certainly not appropriate for someone to be so hostile and abrasive, especially at the front of the house!
author: Vivian T.

description:
I went here for breakfast and wasn't as impressed as thought I would.

Food: 
I ordered the lower haight, which is their egg scramble with mixed vegetables, mozzarella cheese, and topped with a pesto sauce ---according to the menu. The dish came with a choice of potatoes or fruit and I asked for the fruit. The cashier told me they were out of fruit but that I could possibly have a banana. I found that interesting that they couldn't serve the mixed fruit bowl, yet they had bananas and presumably strawberries and other fruits to make crepes. So my friend and I both received our egg dished with cut up bananas. My scramble was ok  tasting, but they forgot to put the pesto on it - that was the reason I ordered it!!

Service:
The server at the cashier station didn't answer our questions very well, but he did come out to our table with waters and we didn't even ask for it. He came by our table twice to see if we wanted refills on our coffee. 

Atmosphere:
The restaurant only had a handful of tables full of customers as it it was early on a weekday morning.

Value:
Each egg scramble was approx $10 and included potatoes and some type of bread. I am limiting carbs at the moment, so I did not feel that it was worth it to just have the egg portion, especially when they had trouble providing the fruit choice over potatoes when it was clearly printed on their menu. 

Since this is a close walk to my apartment, I might be willing to try it again for crepes.
author: Cynthia D.

description: Generous portions, food made really well, amazing outdoor patio in the back, with granite tables that must've been very expensive. I love this place. Not sure why star rating is not higher.
author: D T.

description: DEEEEE - licious!  Get the Hawaiian crepe with a salad (sub for the taters).  It's my second favorite brunch spot in the city.  Unfortunately, it is clearly a favorite of others as well, so expect a crowd...
author: Peter M.

description:
I love me some Squat!!  
Though the quality of food at this new Marina spot isn't as good as the Haight location, it is a much nicer layout, spacious, very clean, and the staff is pretty cool.

I definitely give it 4 stars for the breakfast ONLY (the tofu scramble, crepes and breakfast items are all solid - everything else pretty much blows).
Unfortunately I give it only 2 stars for the location and the wait (which was over 30 minutes for my brother and I this morning). 

The big drawback for me...I'm absolutely not a fan of the Marina crowd.  At all.  
Sitting around listening to a table of 4 guys talk about the fit of their jeans, the fact that girls move better on the tennis court side-to-side (versus what?  front-to-back?) and why celebrities deserve to be harassed by paparazzi...well, it just about makes me lose my appetite.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I have mixed feelings about the Squat & Gobble, especially when it comes to the name of their business. I don't know if it really matters, but I had mentioned to the boy (my lunch time company) that the place looks like the breakfast area in a Days Inn or something. Although, the back patio was much nicer.

The food is fine, really. I might even go so far as to say it was good, but that's a stretch. Perhaps it's good in the same way sushi at the grocery store is good: it's not, really, but it seems appealing at the time. And after wards, you wonder if you should have gotten something else.

I had a Greek salad, which was really a pile of rabbit food with some feta cheese and olives on top. Not awful or anything... I never said I DIDN'T like rabbit food, after all. But while standing in line, I joked to boy about ordering only a crouton, after listening to him bitch about the prices listed on the menu. But then, when my salad came, I was given a thin piece of focaccia bread about the size of a large crouton. No, I'm not exaggerating. Suddenly the crouton joke was a lot less funny after it actually sorta happened.

Anyway I guess what really locks in the three star award is their prices. $8.50 for a mediocre pile of leaves, and although their omelets looked good (and were definitely more substantial than the salad) they were nearly $10. I can't say the food is bad, but I can accurately claim that it's overpriced.
author: Andrea B.

description: I got the savory Marina crepe with a side salad. it was great! The salad was light with a great dressing and the crepe had the perfect blend of flavors. I'll definitely go back for other breakfasts, lunches and the occasional sweet crepe. Try it!
author: Karin Z.

description:
Oh Squat and Gobble.. I feared your name... but it is a testament to my motions!!!  I have only been here hung over!!  and EVERYTHING is always great!!  I wont complain that there is usually a wait or squished seating because they recently opened up a back area that is a walk into a different world!!  haha!!  its so bizarre... its like a mirage of an oasis!! its really cheesy!!  but now i dont have to be crammed next to marina folk!!  
their home fries are killer, omelettes to die for, bagel and lox fuck yeah, pancakes are yummers, bloody mary makes me recover faster.. try it all!!!!  i am usually there the morning after a night I crash out in the city!!!
author: blair k.

description: Squat and Gobble == Crepeville-wannabe == No good.
author: Jess C.

description: Slow. I ordered the simplest thing, two scrambled eggs and bacon and the place isn't even busy. 30 minutes later. The food is just OK to have taken that long.
author: S P.

description: The food was sub-par. I found eggshells in my pancakes, which were sticky and dense. The chicken apple sausages were the size of my pinky. The eggs were dry and bland and the chef was not very accommodating. My favorite part of the meal was the butter that came with my pancakes. Slow service, waited half an hour for brunch. Overall a poor experience. Won't be going back anytime soon and won't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Went there last Saturday with the girlfriends.

Man this place gets really busy. You place your order here and then take your number and find your table. It took a very long time to get 3 salads and they came didn't come out at the same time, which is usually okay but not 15 minutes apart from each other...
The servers/bussers are really great too. Very nice and were very accommodating. Since the line was so long to order and we wanted more wine, our service went ahead and placed the order for us.
Nice Touch.
Food was just okay. None of us had any crepes so I can say anything about that. Would I rush back there, probably not, but it was just okay.
author: Christine S.

description:
why Why WHY have I not reviewed this place before? I was feeling like all my reviews were negative lately, so I wanted to add some positivity in my life and review a 5 star place. I could think of squat.... squat & gobble that is (get it? haha! i'm so lame.)

Never had a bad experience, everything on the menu is great, outdoor patio is always available. Fresh squeezed orange juice = heaven, and the rosemary potatoes are perfect. Can't really say anything bad about this place.
author: Sarah P.

description:
My husband and I were recently in SF visiting cousins and celebrating our one year anniversary. i absolutely loved this place! it was the perfect, cheery hideaway to a busy day of walking and sightseeing. 
The food was delicious and the coffee was yummy.  
Potatoes come with many of the breakfast dishes, but ask to replace the potatoes for fresh fruit instead! its free and sooo good! 
I loved the food and ambiance and would definitely recommend it to others!
author: Lydia R.

description:
Yuck. Squat & Gobble refers to itself as a "Cafe and Crepery". Unfortunately the crepes are terrible. I sure hope they can get by on the cafe part.

Let me explain. To make a crepe - a real crepe - you don't slam all the fruit into it and throw the whole thing on the pan. That's exactly what the kitchen did to our crepes. They came out gross, tasteless and hideously soggy. The contents were basically massacred and all color and flavor cooked away. If S&G can't get a crepe right, they have no business calling themselves a crepery. (This is the part where I restrain myself between drawing a non-flattering linguistic parallel between the word "crepery" and my opinion about the food I was served on my visit.)

I honestly have no idea why this place is getting the kind of ratings people are giving it. While the atmosphere is nice (albeit a bit of a place to be "seen"), the food simply isn't any good. If I was there on an off-day, that's one thing. I'll give S&G one more chance, but if it's anything even remotely like my first experience, I'll never return here again. And I live right down the street, so for me to walk past this place, that's saying something.
author: Gregg G.

description: Really love the atmosphere of this place. The handwritten menu on the chalkboards are a nice touch. Ultimately, the food looks great and the menu has some tasty options. It definitely took me awhile to indecisively settle on what to order. Prices were pretty reasonable, and the food arrives fairly quickly despite the constant inflow of diners. It's a great place to have some brunch while trying to recover from the night before.
author: Patrick L.

description: Went there for a breakfast meeting this morning. The place was not busy at all, and we were the only people at the register..literally, it took the guy almost 10 minutes to ring us up. Perhaps he was new, but there were other staff there that could have helped him out? My meal came before my coffee...and we had to ask for my friend's coffee cake since the server forgot.  I understand if service is not 100% during a busy weekend morning..but it was a Thur am and there were more staff there than patrons..
author: Mimi T.

description:
12/31/07 (Latest Review)
Just got back from eating here, we waited about 45 minutes to get our food, it was cold and it sucked.  

I got "biscuits & gravy" for $8.25 which consisted of two tiny biscuits from a tin that were tasteless and cold 2 eggs and 2 pieces of bacon.  My husband's "French Dip" consisted of a lukewarm and dry cheese steak with no "dip" at all.  

The food was awful, the service was super slow and it was expensive.  Not coming back.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Original Review
I avoided this restaurant solely based on the name when it first came to Chestnut - just not appetizing.  Really, who wants to SQUAT and GOBBLE??  

After I got over the name and tried it out - it wasn't bad.  The food here is fresh and they give u plenty, so you'll be full when you walk out.  But, WARNING - coming here on the weekend is annoying.  Screaming kids, crowded, and long lines.  If you like the Marina crowd, which is aging with rich 30 something moms who don't work and their 1.5 kids - this is your place.  Otherwise, it's to be avoided.  

It's not exactly cheap either, an average sandwich and drink costs about $10 - but it's quite tasty.  So, go on a weekday or off hours or visit one of their other locations.
author: Audra E.

description:
4 stars for the food (maybe), -3 stars for everything else

First of all, this is not "quick food".  Second, service sucks. Third, atmosphere feels too much like Dennys.

Here was our wonderful plan for yesterday's Sunday afternoon:
1. Sleep in
2. 12:30 - Brunch at Squat and Gobble
3. 1: 30 - Movie 2 blocks away 
4. 4PM - Go home with plenty of time to do whatever you do on Sunday nights

Here's what actually happened: 
1. Slept in :)
2. 12:45 - finally made it to S&G (with plenty of time to order/eat, right? 45 min should be enough time, right?)
3. 1:05 - Place order (yes, line took roughly 15-20 min)
4. 1: 15 - Find a table (yes, it takes that long... while we were waiting a lady stormed out because she'd been looking for a table for so long she gave up on eating ?!?!?)
5. 1:20 - Start to panic, no food yet, movie starts in 10 min
6. 1:30 - Still no food, decide to see 1:40 movie instead, ask for help from busboy, he relunctantly agrees to check,  we never hear back.... people who ordered 10 min after us start getting their food.
7. 1:45 - Still no food, I go up to the counter to inform them that we've been waiting for 40 min and have missed our movie
8. 1:50 - Finally get our food.... our afternoon potentially ruined.... with NO APOLOGY from anyone who works there.

Luckily we're not the kind of people who let this ruin our afternoon....we spent some quality time shopping before the 4PM showing.   But still.... I was apalled like I have not been in years.  No tip for you!  And there were at least 2-3 other groups having the same experience.

For those of you that love the crepes so much.... trust me, they're "just ok" here. Try Crepes A Go Go on Union or Polk.  Truly authentic, very fresh ingredients, and no extra sugary stuff on top.
author: Angela T.

description:
Ok I've now been here twice for a weekend brunch and both times were just ok.  The line is long and it can be tough to get a table...

the fresh squeezed OJ was the highlight both times, I wish is was a bottomless glass!

So granted I've never actually ordered a crepe here - and it might very well be my food selection that's the proble, but the food was only Ok both times.

First time I had the grilled chicken sandwich which was good but a little dry.

Yesterday I had the special breakfast burrito which was basically flavorless.  

I'd go back - but mostly for the orange juice!
author: Lauren V.

description:
Save your $$ and just go to IHOP.

I used to live down the street from Squat and Gobble.  I was truly disappointed by my experience there when they first opened in 2007.  The food was heavy and the service was embarrassing.  I recall one time when one of the waiters sat down at a table near us and complained to his friend that he had just been fired.  AWK-WARD... Anyway, we moved to San Diego and that was that.

Flash-forward eighteen months when we came back to SF for a visit with our son.  I wanted to give S&G another chance - I love crepes and maybe I was delusional before. Um, not so much.

Again, the service was embarassingly poor.  We waited 25 minutes for our crepes.  Our friends, who had ordered just minutes before us, had finished their dishes 10 minutes before ours even arrived.  

Our three dishes (all crepes) arrived luke warm, and mine was wrong.  After taking a small bite, my husband sent it back to the ktichen stating that 1) it was wrong, and 2) it was cold. The same crepe returned to me with the appropriate topping splattered across the top.  I think they must have re-heated it in the microwave. Nice.

So, the service was bad, the kitchen staff were idiots, and to be honest, the food just wasn't that good. Their crepes are so heavy - hardly authentic of true crepe legacy.  

If you want real crepes, go to the little crepe cafe on Union Street.  They're delicious and lite, and the atmosphere is so much better.  

If you want a family-friendly restaurant in the Marina, go to Mel's, IHOP, or Johnny Rockets. The service, at least, is always good at those spots.
author: Love Z.

description:
Food was fine.

However, I did not realize that eating here would feel like I was going to church.  For the 1.5 hours I was here, it exclusively played Contemporary Christian music so that between each bite I had to be serenaded about the glory of Jesus Christ.  I'm sure that the fact that I am not particularly religious added to the annoyance, but personal religious beliefs aside, it is pretty distracting to hear this awful music and it killed the experience for me.

If you like the whine of contemporary christian music to go along with your brunch, then you can add a couple of stars.  For me, I prefer a nondenominational restaurant experience.
author: N L.

description:
Feeling brave, we decided to abandon our usual Chestnut Street breakfast spots in order to give S&G a try.  I was not disappointed.

Although there was a line 15 people deep when we walked in, the line moved quickly.  Kudos to the cashier for moving people through so fast!  We ordered Huevos Rancheros and the Mexican Chicken Salad. Both were delivered to our table in under 10 minutes - speedy service and our waiter was really nice.   The Huevos Rancheros were good but nothing overly special. The Mexican Chicken Salad was special - it was huge and full of great ingredients and flavors - a yummy dressing, lots of spicy chicken and a very generous helping of avocado on top (my favorite).  

I'd give this restaurant five stars if they would rethink the decor.  There is just too much going on and I felt like I was in a Vegas buffet.  Lose the pear/apple plastic booth covers and the gaudy wall pictures and the place would look much better! 

I also loved that dogs are allowed. I felt bad that we left our pooch at home. She loves crepes.
author: Megan L.

description: My new favorite breakfast place in the marina, not to mention love it for lunch too! Delicious crepes and yummy salads! Good service and good fresh OJ too!
author: Jenny I.

description:
While strolling around the Castro area, my b/f and I decided to stop somewhere since hunger pangs were beginning to hit us. Since we had the dog with us, obviously outdoor seating was a must. We came across the Squat & Gobble and not only for their name (it made me laugh) but also for their menu, we stopped here. 

My first impression wasn't the most positive. Since there was only a couple table available, we decided that I would order and he would wait with the dog. The waiters came by in a fit telling him he couldn't sit there without ordering anything. He had to explain to them (to the point of one of the waiters coming to the line and asking if I was with him) that someone was ordering. It was kind of rude and I was really put off by it. 

So we ordered: I had the Caesar salad and he got the south of the border omelet. Both were okay. He liked the black beans in his but I was surprised at how little the salad was (especially for the price). The area we sat in was a highlight since people watching was readily available. 

Not sure if I'd go here again. I think we'd try to find a different outdoor venue for lunch next time.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I came here recently for brunch with friends of mine visiting me from out of town and while MY meal was awesome, their's came out less than par.

My girlfriend ordered the soup and sandwich combo, assuming the soup would be chicken noodle (which was the advertised soup du jour on that particular day).  Instead, she got clam chowder.  She also ordered her sandwich with toasted sourdough bread.  It came out on wheat.  Her husband ordered the salmon sandwich, but it came out dry and flavor-less.

All in all, a not so perfect experience.  What makes up for it, though, is the colorful decor and the big front windows, which they'll prop open on sunny days and flip the heat lamps on from the street, making a cozy window spot one of the best seats in the joint.
author: Katie C.

description:
Squat and Gobble is usually my default place to go for some bomb diggity hangover food, but the Chestnut street location is seriously lacking.  Ive never had such a bland experience at squat and gobble.

My pesto chicken sandwich was extremely flavorless.  Pesto is supposed to be lively and full of flavor, right?  How do you even create bland pesto?  And, the tomato "soup" that I got as a side was more like chunky ass stewed tomatoes out of a can.  Nasty.

My friend's dish was even worse.  She got the salmon linguine.  I know that salmon is one of the fishier-smelling fishes, but when they brought that thing out to the table, I had to fight my gag reflex.

One positive thing about this location is that its really nice inside.  However, I'll take a something slightly more run down with better food, than a foo-foo atmosphere with bland pesto.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
The first time I went here, I was with a bunch of friends coming from an improv show. We stared at the huge menu for 20 minutes trying to decide what to get. The menu is actually 6 or 7 menus of elegant chalking hung up on the wall. And when we were finally ready, *then* they told us they had closed for the evening. Not cool.

The second time I went here, I was with one friend and it was the middle of the day. So we got food! Very cool.

There is a strategy to Squat & Gobble. First, I recommend going with someone you feel comfortable sharing food with because this is a good place to do halfsies. Second, I recommend going on an empty stomach because it is well worth it to get both a savory meal crepe and a savory dessert crepe. Third, I recommend asking the management to open up a store in the peninsula because it is frustratingly far away!
author: Stephen L.

description: Delicious fresh sandwiches and salads. My dad tries Reuben sandwiches everywhere he goes and this is the best one he's ever had. I enjoy the grilled chicken breast on a fresh foccacia bread. The salad is always fresh and topped in a delicious house dressing. There are so many flavors for their Italian sodas. It has great sidewalk tables and a hidden back patio. Its the perfect place to just stop in for something quick, healthy, affordable while still with a sit down cafe feel.
author: Kari G.

description:
My friend and I walked down the street from her place for some brunch after a night out.  It was surprisingly empty at 11:30 on a Saturday.  I ordered their special omelette of the day - aparagus, roasted red peppers, mushrooms, fontina, spinach.  Very good!  I think it was $9.50 - expensive for breakfast, but a lot of food.  Their omelettes come with potatoes and toast too.  All in all, with OJ and coffee I spent about $15, which to me is a lot to spend on breakfast.  My friend ordered the $7 fruit bowl - decent size.  But seriously, $7 just for fruit?

The food is good and I would go back next time I'm in town!
author: Jen G.

description: My friend and I ducked in here on a rainy day to warm up and dry off. The staff was so friendly and the food was pretty good. I had the eggs benedict, which was good; however, my friend's pancakes (which she kindly shared a few bites of) were some of the best I've ever had. The whipped cream that accompanied it was exactly how whipped cream should be-- none of that from-the-can junk. It was a great place for a rainy-day breakfast!
author: Leslie S.

description: I have been to Squat and Gobble several times.  I have had the french toast, waffle and the eye opener (two eggs any styles, with potatoes and toast).  The food is always good, fresh and quick.   Oh ya, and really really cheap..
author: Sissy T.

description: This place looks like it would be good, but all three times I've tried it have ended in disappointment. The food is really not tasty, the ambiance is just ok and it gets a big "pass" moving forward.
author: Julia S.

description:
We ate here twice over the weekend.  I love the crab cake breakfast.  It is so good.  The quality was very high.  The place was clean and bright.  
I guess it's not the typical SF place in terms of it being old and quaint.. but once in a while it's nice to have bright and clean.
coffee is good and refills are self serve.. nice..
author: James R.

description:
If you're in the Marina, and you need some reliable food, and you have no idea where else to go or you're in a hurry, Squat & Gobble is a good choice.   They have a decent selection of beer on tap, a few decent wines, and a menu that will cater to all tastes with food that probably won't burn lasting memories of dining glory into your cortex, but also won't disappoint.  It was also easy to deal with, really relaxed, and a good speed for some fuel before heading out for the night.

My 4 stars for S&G could just as easily be 3.  There are certainly better restaurants within easy reach.
author: Jay M.

description:
Okay, I am trying to make sense here, but I don't get their name. It sounds stupid for a dining place. Ordered Burger medium well with fries and orange juice. Their orange juices are freshly squeezed and I loved it, but I found a hair in my juice. 
Next scene: the burger was medium rare and it felt like I was eating a piece of raw meat with a minimal slice of bread. Management decided to compensate me for the mess up with chocolate cake. That was nice of them. 
A plus side was the parsley flakes on my fries. :)
author: Artimmis G.

description:
This place has grown on me.  I used to not like it.  The sandwiches are pretty weak.  The burger is huge but somehow only a step above fast food (if you want a better burger go to johnny rockets).  

But then I discovered the omelets.  Not amazing, but pretty good and reasonably priced - less than Judy's across the street, and they come with potatoes to boot, which Judy's does not.  This is now my go-to breakfast place.

The staff is always accommodating and nice though not outwardly "friendly".
author: Brian N.

description: Went in for the first time ever on a Wednesday shortly before 11:00 am for brunch.  The line was long, and only one person was working behind the counter.  She was also serving as the barista, so time spent making coffee and whatnot was time not spent taking customers' orders.  The staff, as a whole, was moderately friendly, and the food was good but not great.  Even though there seemed to be an adequate number of busboys, some tables were left unbussed with old food and plates on them.  I found this to be quite unpleasant.  What was more disturbing, however, is that a hunting show was being aired on TV.  Why choose a channel where animals are being shot as a backdrop for eating?  I'm a vegetarian and found this very disconcerting and, certainly, an odd choice for viewing at a restaurant.  It is not likely I will return, at least not to this particular location.
author: Maggie F.

description: Mmmmmmmmmm.  So glad we happened I on this place!  Quality, fresh foods from an ample menu.  We had a salmon Cobb salad as well as a seafood pasta.  All fish items were perfectly cooked in perfect in texture and taste, including shrimp, mussels and clams.  Not easy to say that about many places.  Service was very friendly and generous.  We were offered refills on our sodas three times.  Very kid friendly and warm. Wish we had one of these where I live!
author: Holly G.

description:
This place was packed during a lazy summer Saturday lunch hour.  

Although the line was long, it went pretty quickly.  I think the the menu board is a piece of art.  Sitting is quite limited, and you need to be quick, but the staff are pretty helpful in getting you settled down.  

The omelettes and crepes were delicious, but the rosemary potatoes could have been better prepared.
author: X X.

description:
Let's face it, I'm a casual person and I get even more casual on the weekends. I'm not ashamed to say I wake up on Saturday mornings by a phone call from my buddy, which I take from bed. I then roll into my closet, roll into my running clothes, then roll my hair into a ponytail. No shower. Teeth may be brushed. Maybe. I pick my friend up at her place and we head to Crissy Field for a run. If the day calls for it, we'll even run across the bridge. 

So you ask, "isn't this a review on Squat and Gobble?" Why yes it is. Because after our runs we normally head here for either an eggs b-fast or giganto salad, and luscious hot coffee. There is sometimes a line, but we're still reading the menu on the board. There are also lots of families and other post-run people, or people who look like they went running. Or my favorite...those that have complete faces of makeup, jewelry and running clothes on. Oh wait, those people did lap me out at CF about an hour ago.

Oh, and (no joke) my friend and I did spot the King of Jordon eating there once. He sat right there at that shared table upfront, with a whole entourage there, or secret service, whatever. Black SUVs double parked outside. They wouldn't let anyone else in the restaurant. He even gave my friend the "smile nod". I mean it was like the King of Jordon was eating there eating a Florentine Omelet or whatever...wait he was. 

Anyway, the best part about this particular location on Chesty, is its pleasant, sheltered-from-the-wind, sunny outdoor patio. There are water features and plants. I would seriously consider having my wedding reception there if I was seriously considering having a wedding right now which I am not, thank you. You can sit there and soak up the sun while its 60s and windy out of the shelter. Drink bottomless cups of coffee until you run out of topics to banter about. That's a Saturday morning for ya. 

That's about it with the S&G. It's healthy living at it's best. The food is above average. How about a solid "B". But that back patio rocks. 

Ok, time for my shower.
author: Janet C.

description: I've been to a ton of places like this by now. Food quality is good but not particularly amazing. There are lots of options though! I did appreciate that. I got a savory crepe (forgot the name), it was vegetarian with a mexcian sauce that was great. I enjoyed my food, and overall it was a satisfying.
author: Lillian S.

description: I frequent this establishment on a daily basis.  Everyone is very friendly and professional.  I have very specific dietary needs and they are always willing to bend over backwards to make sure I'm happy.  I'll continue going here and referring my friends.
author: craig b.

description:
Doesn't really compare to Crepevine, BUT still really good. I just don't like how this place closes earlier than Crepevine.. maybe that's why I prefere Crepevine over this place.. Oh wells. I love their breakfast! TRIPLE GOBBLE! aha best of everything. You get pancakes, bacon/sausages/ and whatever I forgot. Sucks it doesn't come with house potatoes tho.. I love their house pots too... pretty good and chunky! 
What else? Oh it's packed on sundays.
author: Johnny T.

description:
I went to an early dinner with a friend here and the food was pretty good (I had the turkey sandwich with sprouts and a tasty side salad). The service was excellent and the restaurant was not very crowded, but that could've been because it was a Sunday evening in the middle of a holiday weekend.

The style of the menus in this place and the food selection remind me of the Crepevine...wonder if they're sister restaurants?
author: Art D.

description:
Comparing this to the Grove across the street. 

1st: Breakfast items are better - omelets are great here. 

2nd: More families and kids here then at Grove

3rd: Heat lamps outside if you are sitting outside - Grove does not have this. 

4th: Food is just better. 

5th: Grove still attracts the young crowd recovering from hangovers or the internet cafe junkie surfing, sipping and people watching...

Your choice....but, if you are going for the food - Squat is just better.
author: Kristina A.

description:
I've been going here before class to get a quick dinner lately. The service is great and my orders are always right on time. It's usually pretty quiet around dinner time, lots of people on computers typing away.
There was a really annoying woman in there last night and I almost pitched my huevos rancheros at her, but that would have punished me more than her...
Anyway, good place, decent amount of choices, friendly and attentive staff.
author: Rachel M.

description: Highly recommend this spot - good service, great food especially the 29.99 nightly special for 2 which includes a shared appetizer, 2 entrees and 2 glasses of wine.
author: Barbara H.

description:
BEWARE THE SEAFOOD

The linguine with mussels dish:
Tastes great, but they bang the mussels around, which leaves flakes of shell bits in the pasta, which crack when you are eating the food. its a major danger for your teeth. This has happened to me 4/5 times that I have ordered this dish.

The salmon:
1) A friend and I ate lunch here today. My friend ordered a salmon plate of some kind. She has been sick from food poising all afternoon.
2) I ordered a salmon sandwich a few weeks ago. It was not cooked all the way when it was delivered to the table, so I sent it back to the kitchen.

The seafood clearly has ongoing cooking/preparation issues that pose major health risks. I used to love this place; but after these ongoing problems, I won't be eating here again.
author: charles b.

description: This place was amazing. The service was great, the food wasn't TOO pricey, the food was filling and soo soooooo good. I want to come regularly. The line was noisey, the place was bustling but it really doesn't matter, it was just busy. If those things are faults the food makes up for it. Also, you pay up front which is a nice trend because then you don't have to worry about the check after eating.
author: Clare R.

description:
Great place for Crepes. Food is quick, if you beat the rush.*

Went to Squat & Goggle for breakfast this morning.
Nice place. Great for Crepes, which is their specialty by the way.

First upon walking in you notice a HUGE black board to your left listing all that is available for you to order.
Decide what you want while standing in line & then order at the register counter. ( I recommend, if you come while it's busy, to have someone find some seats while you wait in line & order for them.)
They give you a number on a small stand, then you go find a place to sit.
Whatever you do, get the FRESH SQUEEZED Orange Juice (it's as fresh as it gets), cause it's HARDCORE DELICIOUS & comes in a nice sized glass. Lip smacking goodness. Just like Grandma makes it.

You can get a fancy coffee, but the house blend is GREAT & it comes with FREE Refills at your table. NICE.
Though I did get the Cafe Au Lait & it was perfect.

I was there with 5 others & EVERYONE really enjoyed the food.
We sat out back, which is outdoor seating. They have a retractable awning, which is nice & weather friendly. Plus heating lamps.

Don't worry about the name. I didn't have to Squat at all, but I did Gobble up all my food.

I would recommend this place & I look forward to eating there again.
Try it for yourself & make sure you have a Crepe :)

*I gave it 4 stars, because the wait for the food was excessive, but worth it...
author: Dan B.

description:
Actual conversation I had at Squat and Gobble:

"Can I substitute the pumpkin bread instead of english muffin?"  "No, the pumpkin bread is more expensive."  "Well, how about I pay the additional amount more that the pumpkin bread is, and don't get the english muffin at all, since I'm paying for the cost of the muffin in the dish."  Blank stare, followed by denial.   In other words, any substitution beyond egg-whites doesn't fly.  

That said, Squat and Gobble is not bad.  However, it also is not great.  It, like many places on Chestnut Street, is somewhere in between (although to be fair, my comments apply to all S&G's, not just the Marina one).  The breakfast here is pretty solid for sure.  So is lunch/dinner.  So why not more stars and why do I not eat here more?  Because I'm yet to find something that really makes me want Squat and Gobble.  

The people that work at S&G are nice, and helpful, even if they don't substitute for me. 

It is a comfortable place, and definitely should be tried.

I'm not a huge fan of crepes, but if you are, they have a lot of them, both dessert and otherwise.
author: Brett J.

description: Great service (even with a 15 mo. Baby). Thanks for a nice and easy Sunday night!
author: Preston L.

description:
It was good but not spectacular enough for me to give a 4. The spaghettini with prawns was good. The noodles were a little too cooked, I would have preferred them to be al dente. The crepe was good but it just had too much strawberry jame and nutella on top too. I would have been happy to just have the strawberry and nutella inside. I'll remember that for next time.

We sat in the patio area which was nice and cozy. 

I'll probably go back and try some other things and I may change my rating.
author: Joie G.

description:
Most exciting for the menu of possibilities there.  Had two crepes though both were brought door by an inordinate amount of onions that tasted like nothing.

Would love to head back and try some of the breakfast specials.
author: jeremy S.

description:
Concur with  brooke,  the marina S&G should be rated higher. 
After doing my morning jog from russian hill to marina d. 
I stopped in here for Breky and a Latte. 
The atmosphere and food is relaxing and brilliant
author: Michael y.

description: Came here starving one morning after a late flight in the night before & really enjoyed the breakfast.  I had a simple order of granola and yogurt and was impressed by the large portion for a relatively cheap price.  All the other plates I saw were pretty big as well.  The atmosphere was pleasant and the service was good.  Nice decor as well.
author: Lisa P.

description:
My experiences with Squat & Gobble have been positive.  First of all, the name of this place is a built-in ice breaker.  Whenever I bring people here, they tell me some comical story about a turkey, which is a wonderful way to kick off a meal.  Also, sometimes I crave breakfast food at night, and I want to enjoy it in a non-diner setting.  S&G is a perfect fit.

The restaurant itself is comfortable and the prices are reasonable.  The crepes and omelets are good and the salads are huge.  I've never come here on a weekend morning, so I can't write about the wait or the volume of this place when it's packed.  I am withholding that fifth star because there's nothing really amazing about this place, but I've had consistently good service, good food, and good conversation here.
author: Veggie J.

description:
Pros: Free wifi, tons of outlets, delicious desert crepes, good lighting, kind staff that refilled my water cup numerous times during the 4 hours I worked there

Cons: A little bit expensive, sandwich was only barely OK. A little dry.

I'd go back, but I wouldn't be excited about it, and I'd only go so just so I can get some work done outside the house. However, it's still too noisy to get too much work done. 

Possibly biasing my review slightly to the negative: when I was there, the spoiled-looking girl at the next table spent 20 minutes bitching out her financial advisor on the phone-- hello, it's a recession, you're not the only one losing money! Yikes, what a creep. I wanted her financial advisor to dump her over the phone for such verbal abuse.
author: Samantha B.

description: Great place for breakfast in the Marina!  Love their eggs benedict (I'm picky about my hollandaise sauce and their's is good!), waffles, mimosas, and coffee!  Food is always fresh, staff is friendly and efficient, and there is something for everyone on their menu.
author: Nicole W.

description:
This really is a place for gobbling some real decent and reliable grub. 
I don't know how the squatting comes into play... eww... actually I don't want to further explore the connotations behind the name.

Been here 3 times and have enjoyed a savory crepe (forgot which one) for brunch, the raspberry and ricotta sweet crepe for dessert, and the 1/2 eggplant sandwich w/house potatoes & mixed green salad for lunch! I hardly get just a veggie sandwich but the eggplant sounded very good... and it certainly was! roast eggplant, peppers, mozzarella, tomatoes, and pesto all sandwiched in between a toasted ciabatta roll. yumsters! the eggplant sandwich definitely tops my list of favorite sandwiches! I didn't like my sweet crepe so much... the sauce/syrup was good but it was stuffed with wayyy too much ricotta cheese.. which made the crepe too soft. I like my crepes a little crispy. 

Nonetheless, they have a good menu selection and good portion sizes of sweet, savory, healthy, and of course some guilty/comfort choices as well all for under $10. Haven't had their salads yet.. but that thing is piled up with so much lettuce, it looks like it can feed a cow or whatever animal eats grass!

NOTE and a BIG PLUS for.................  FREE INTERNET  !!!
Im not sure if its with all the Squat and Gobble's, but this location has free WIFI!! with outlets for your laptop chargers too!
author: Sue Y.

description:
This was very good. 
I had a pesto chicken crepe. 
Very Yummy!
The place was very clean.
The best things are the small things and there best small thing was the ice water.....they have lemon and mint soaked ice water...so yummy, cool and fresh!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Best fries in the city!

Best crepes! Delicious mimosas! I come here all the time....do I get tired of it? NO!)))
author: Lerka J.

description: The service here lately has been great. In the past it's been hit or miss. Way to be squat & gobble for stepping it up! I am a creature of habit so I usually only get a couple things I like on the menu. The Asian chicken salad sans cilantro & onions is really tasty and a decent portion.
author: Justin H.

description:
Their menu is delish and contains mostly healthy choices. Love the chicken pesto (no pine nuts!) crepe and mozzarella and tomato salad. Love the strong outdoor heaters that you keep you toasty even on the foggiest of days and nights. Love, love, love the doughy crepes. Hate the wait for food preparation - as in waiting twenty minutes for a mozzarella tomato salad (no cooking involved) to be tossed together is just ridic. Really ridic.

But, if I am not in too much of a rush to eat, I would still come here again to try more things on their menu, since their prices are pretty decent for yummy food.
author: Jaclyn T.

description:
This place has really good food.  I enjoy every bite of my meal. 
The service is great and fast. I can even say they have the best desert crepes!
I really love their back patio. It's very clean, cozy, and romantic.I always have great experience there.
author: Jenna F.

description: I've been to Squat and Gobble a few times over the past month or so and have had the most delicious meals and fabulous service!  The back patio is a great spot for weekend brunch!  Be sure to try the Crab Benedict!  The new General Manager, Scott, is FANTASTIC!!!
author: kristan l.

description:
Marina moms and hipster LDAC-ers, unite!

The fries are always perfect. (one star)
The spaghetti bolognese is too pricey, but always tasty. (one star)
I almost always pass on the crepes since it's not a crepe place (no star)
Friendly service (one star).

Tada :)
author: dj z.

description:
Squat and Gobble is normally the last place you'd find me eating but I happened to go there late on a Friday night and I was pleasantly surprised to see they've changed their dinner menu! They have the most amazing deal in the city right now for dinner. You get one app, two entrees and any two glasses of wine for $30! 

We had steamed, curry mussels for the appetizer. I had a salmon dish on a skillet with butternut squash and green beans and my date had a flank steak with creamy polenta and veggies. We washed it down with two glasses of Pinot. I'm telling you, the food was delish and you cannot beat the price. I'm not sure how long their going to be running this special but I've already been there twice for dinner.
author: Venessa M.

description: Chestnut street is full of morning eateries and Squat was my go-to for years when I lived in the hood.  The expanded back patio is epic on those sunny days, and the crossant egg sandwich (substitute fruit for the potatoes if you're done with that starch thing) is the ultimate hangover tool.
author: Dave M.

description:
This place is awesome!
I love omlettes...and if you do too...This is the place for you!
ahhhhhhhhhh
The fruit is Super Delish!!!
The water with a hint of citrus:D
There was a huge line but it moved pretty swiftly. The people were very kind and the service was splendid. I didnt get a chance to sit on the back patio...but i'll be back. Oh yeah, totally worth the wait!
author: Melanie G.

description:
I was surprised that I liked this place. We had crepes frequently growing up and lately I have found myself craving them. We were in the neighborhood mid-afternoon and decided to stop in. I ordered the Fruity Nutella. Bananas, Strawberries and Blueberries with Nutella in a crepe and a side of whipped cream. We sat on the back patio in the sun on a beautiful day. That helped ALOT. Plants, Fountains, sunshine, it was all good. My crepe was good, but would have been better if the fruit was not so cooked. I guess some people prefer cooked fruit, but I like mine as raw as possible. It was still quite tasty. I did not try the Italian crepe my husband ordered, but he was quite happy with it. 
The service here is just ok, they forgot to give my husband his Coke. It was also past the lunch hour so it was not at all crowded, and quite mellow.
author: Kathleen Y.

description: The Marina Crepe and fresh squeezed OJ are the best and are my usuals!!!
author: Louis C.

description: This location is unsanitary! I came here a few weeks ago with my family for brunch, my husband, son, and I waited at a table for about 20 minutes for our food (i guess understandable since they were super busy) when my crepe arrived IT HAD A HAIR right in the middle of it toped with white poudered sugar. So i told the waiter he came up in front of me put his fingers into the crepe took the hair out, apologized, and went to get another one which took ANOTHER 15 minutes while everyone was done eating at my table (which if they waited for my food their's would get cold) , my son is 10 months old and it was hard waiting ANOTHER 15 min for the food to be ready because they had HAIR in my food. So when it came out finally , the crepe was super dry and i just couldnt wait any longer. NOT going back there for sure.
author: Inna R.

description:
This was my first meal in San Francisco and I loved it, really good prices for the amount of food you're getting. The menu is extensive and had me pondering for 10 mins before I decided on an "upper haight" omelette which was delicious and ended up serving me as a breakfast/lunch and had me full till the evening. 
But my favorite part hands down is their outdoor patio tucked in the back! The place looked cute from the front and had a few seating spaces outside, but as i was about to settle inside, i heard a dad nearby asking his little toddler if he wanted to sit at the outside patio due to the lovely weather...so I got up and followed them and that was the first awesome decision of my Thursday morning..It was gorgeous! Foliage and flowers and vines everywhere, really cute furniture and such an isolated feel. With the sun shining down and all the cute couples sitting all around me it was a perfect morning.
author: Veronika Z.

description: Not bad, not great... Pretty good for morning, brunch or lunch. I like their savory crepes and some of their eggs Benedict. The dessert is pretty good. I like hanging here outside during a sunny day. Nothing to rant or rave for but pretty nice. Bugs me that they have something on the menu they haven't carried in years. Seriously? Update it then.
author: Natasha M.

description:
this is a decent cafe, but I would not return here after today. It's pretty dern cold outside and they insist on keeping the front door open. There's a cold draft blowing in and all the customers are in their coats.

Why don't you just put a sandwich board saying you're open on the sidewalk? I would leave but unfortunately I've already ordered my food.

Not impressed with the management.
author: Terry D.

description: Menu is overwhelming but all our orders were good. We enjoyed the breakfast here.
author: pac s.

description: The staff is very attentive and friendly.  The decor bright and inviting   The menu is large with breakfast served all day plus asian, pasta, salads, sandwiches and crepes. The chocolate nutella crepe with ice cream was wonderful.   The prices are very reasonable too.   We would recommend it.
author: Richard N.

description: Excellent find!  French toast was amazing AND beautiful.  The bread they used was great, cinnamon flavor.  I think the whipped cream was homemade.  Staff very helpful in pointing us in the right direction for our exploring that day.
author: Kathleen K.

description:
Stopped in today for a late brunch...the food is typical Squat and Gobble fare (salads, sandwiches, crepes) but what set this location apart was the service-everything was spot on.  We waited a bit for a table outside but once seated we must have had at least 5 different people help us with everything from constantly checking on our water situation to refilling my friend's coke three times, free of charge.
Great addition to the marina.
author: phil h.

description:
Very cute place for brunch. Its another crepevine, only its not as gloomy and dim like crepevine. Its located in the heart of  marina and cow hollow, making it perfect for a nice walk  or shopping after a meal at squat and gobble. Woke up on a nice sunny sunday and my friend called to ask if i wanted to grab brunch with him. I told him I don't want to eat around richmond or sunset...I wanted to try some place different. He told me to get ready and he'll think of some place. After he picked me up he told me we could eat on Chestnut street for they have a few selections. We drove by Squat and Gobble and decided to try it out. 

I ordered the Marina crepe which was filled with salmon, spinach, onion, artichokes, tomatoes and mozzarella cheese. It came with a side of mixed green salad tossed in a vinaigrette dressing. Didn't like the crepe that much but it was one of the best salad I've ever had!

Will take some girlfriends there soon. I think I will skip the crepe this time and just order the half sandwich and salad combo.
author: Jenny K.

description:
WOW seriously worst service ever. The food was decent but I will NEVER go back to this place again. My friend and I went to the Marina location for dinner. The server was a little snooty but we still enjoyed our meal and a few rounds of wine. We split the $66 bill in half - $33 each. 

I look at my bank account the next day to discover that the server ran my card for the $33 and the $66. I called the manager the next day about the problem. He took my information down and then told me that he couldn't speak to me right then because of their lunch rush but would call me back. :P He didn't call me back. So I called him back the next day. Basically he suggested that my party ran up the additional charges without me knowing. Hello, I said it was just me and my friend. Thanks for suggesting that my friend is trying to scam me. Actually, your establishment is trying to scam me. His response was "well its just weird because it's for 2 different charges." Doofus! The errant charge is exactly double the legitimate charge. He then told me that he needed to get back to me because he had a line out of the door. You're a manager. It's your job is to handle the all of restaurant's issues - especially when your server fucks up something financial. 

He asked me to fax in my statement showing both charges. Apparently he didn't have time to look in the system. At this point I am livid. So I told him I'd call my bank and have them fix it. 

I called my bank, they took the errant charge off. Thanks for having my back bank.

Squat and Gobble, you suck. 

Yelpers, if you choose to go here, use cash. And trust that if you have a problem, the manager will be too busy to assist you.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
My friend and I tried the Squat & Gobble in the Haight at the recommendation of one of his friends, and it was definitely a good choice.  Good enough that we came here the very next day.

I wasn't too impressed with the crepes at the Haight location, but I absolutely loved everything about their garden salad, and I suspect that my friend felt the same way, because we both ended up ordering just salads when we came here.

The spinach salad I had was amazing!  Beautiful, super-fresh leaves perfectly dressed with JUST enough poppyseed dressing, and generously topped with crisp-sweet red onion, sugared walnuts, nuggets of blue cheese, and a piece of focaccia on the side.  And I should add that this is one HUGE salad you get for eight bucks.  I'm a big, six foot tall guy who works out almost daily, and even I couldn't finish more than just over half of this salad.  I took the rest home and it held up fine in the fridge until dinner time.

My friend had a Southwestern-style salad topped with grilled chicken, and judging by his reaction it was every bit as good as mine.

Three stars, though it should really be three and a half, as I appreciate any non-Asian restaurant that actually serves pots of loose leaf tea, especially when that tea is houji cha (roasted Japanese green tea).
author: James L.

description:
